label.plain: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:

field.label: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:
field.value: HBCUvc exists to transform who participates in and benefits from venture capital by building durable pathways between historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs), investors, and founders. Our vision is an inclusive innovation economy where talent from under-capitalized communities has sustained access to capital, networks, and ownership opportunities. We do this by preparing emerging investors, activating alumni capital, and supporting founders at the earliest stages—shifting venture capital from a closed system to a more participatory, long-term engine for economic mobility and institutional wealth creation.

label.plain: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.

field.label: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.
field.value:
HBCUvc operates at the intersection of talent development, capital access, and ecosystem building. Our core activities focus on preparing individuals to participate meaningfully in the investment ecosystem and ensuring that founders connected to HBCUs can access early-stage capital and networks.
We run investor education programs that train students, professionals, and alumni in venture fundamentals, sourcing, and diligence, helping participants build real investing experience and long-term career pathways. Through our alumni and angel investor initiatives, we activate individual capital—particularly first-time and emerging investors—to support early-stage companies while building collective ownership and accountability.
We also convene founders, investors, and institutional partners through targeted summits, workshops, and curated communities that emphasize trust, relationship-building, and practical capital readiness over traditional pitch competitions. These engagements are designed to strengthen local and national innovation ecosystems connected to Black communities.
As the organization matures, HBCUvc is increasingly focused on building scalable infrastructure—curriculum, systems, and capital pathways—that allow our impact to extend beyond individual programs. Rather than operating as a one-off fellowship model, we are evolving into a platform that enables sustained participation in venture ecosystems, aligning incentives across individuals, institutions, and capital providers.

label.plain: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

field.label: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:
field.value:
Since its founding, HBCUvc has built a national ecosystem connecting historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs) to venture capital careers, capital, and long-term ownership opportunities. What began as an effort to expose HBCU students to venture capital has evolved into a durable pipeline of investors, operators, and ecosystem leaders reshaping how capital flows into under-capitalized communities.
To date, HBCUvc has supported thousands of students, alumni, founders, and faculty through programs spanning early exposure, career placement, and capital deployment. Alumni have gone on to work at leading venture firms, launch investment vehicles, and actively invest in early-stage companies. In 2024 alone, HBCUvc alumni mobilized over $10 million into Black-founded startups, either as angel investors or through their professional roles—evidence of the compounding returns of sustained investment in people and networks.
HBCUvc’s impact extends beyond individuals to institutions and systems. Our faculty engagement initiatives have equipped educators to reach more than 9,000 students, embedding venture and entrepreneurship knowledge directly into HBCU classrooms. Alumni now sit at firms managing over $1.45 billion in assets under management, increasing long-term influence over institutional capital allocation.
Through initiatives like the State of Black Venture Report, HBCUvc also contributes field-level impact by producing data-driven research that tracks funding disparities and holds the venture ecosystem accountable over time.
Collectively, HBCUvc’s impact lies in building durable capital pathways—transforming access into sustained participation, ownership, and influence within the innovation economy.

label.plain: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

field.label: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

label.plain: Describe the long-term vision for your work and how, at scale, your work will help create a world free from systemic oppression.

field.label: Describe the long-term vision for your work and how, at scale, your work will help create a world free from systemic oppression.
field.value:
HBCUvc’s long-term vision is a venture ecosystem where access to capital, ownership, and decision-making power is not limited by institutional pedigree or inherited networks. We envision a world in which individuals and institutions historically excluded from venture capital—particularly those connected to historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs)—are not only participating in innovation economies, but shaping them.
Systemic oppression in venture capital is sustained by concentration: capital, knowledge, and networks remain controlled by a narrow set of actors, while undercapitalized communities are positioned only as labor or consumers. HBCUvc addresses this imbalance by building durable pathways into venture capital that convert talent into investors, employees into allocators, and institutions into long-term stakeholders.
At scale, our work dismantles exclusion not through one-time interventions, but through compounding systems change. By preparing individuals to deploy capital, activating alumni as angel investors, and embedding venture knowledge within HBCU institutions, we shift power upstream—where decisions about capital formation and allocation are made.
Our vision is not simply to increase representation within existing systems, but to expand who has the capacity to invest, build, and own. Over time, this creates new economic engines rooted in undercapitalized communities, reduces dependency on extractive capital models, and establishes venture capital as a tool for long-term economic mobility and institutional wealth creation rather than gatekeeping and exclusion.

label.plain: Describe the specific initiatives, projects, or investments you intend to make in the next year that move you toward your long-term vision for systemic change.

field.label: Describe the specific initiatives, projects, or investments you intend to make in the next year that move you toward your long-term vision for systemic change.
field.value:
Over the next year, HBCUvc will pilot an angel co-investment coordination model designed to expand the pool of active capital within the HBCU alumni community and move accredited investor capital off the sidelines in a safe, trusted, and collective way.
We will convene a cohort of approximately 30 accredited HBCU alumni angels and partner with leading Black fund managers who will act as deal leads. These trusted GPs will allocate space within vetted investments for our angel community, providing professional diligence, structure, and alignment. Individual angels will be able to participate with investments as low as $1,000, lowering risk and enabling first-time or emerging investors to engage without large upfront commitments.
When the angel cohort collectively demonstrates conviction by committing at least $25,000 to a given opportunity, HBCUvc will match that amount with an additional $25,000 from a dedicated co-investment pool—amplifying the capital deployed to the entrepreneur while concentrating economic power through coordinated action.
In 2026, this pilot will support up to three investments. This is intentionally a learning year focused on testing whether community-coordinated capital—anchored by trusted Black fund managers—can function as a viable, repeatable pathway for expanding early-stage capital access. Insights from this pilot will inform whether and how HBCUvc builds a longer-term platform for coordinated angel investing.

label.plain: Catalytic Funding prioritizes applications that support organizations to test new and unproven ideas, models, or methods. Please describe how your proposed work is innovative and distinct from your core operating model.

field.label: Catalytic Funding prioritizes applications that support organizations to test new and unproven ideas, models, or methods.  Please describe how your proposed work is innovative and distinct from your core operating model.
field.value:
This pilot is innovative because it treats capital coordination—not just capital access—as the core intervention.
Rather than asking undercapitalized individuals to become sophisticated investors overnight or requiring large individual check sizes, this model lowers barriers while preserving discipline. Angels invest alongside trusted Black general partners who lead the deal, conduct diligence, and set terms. HBCUvc’s role is not to replace professional investors, but to aggregate, coordinate, and amplify community capital in alignment with experienced allocators.
The matching mechanism introduces a novel incentive structure: collective conviction unlocks additional capital. By requiring angels to coordinate $25,000 before a match is deployed, the model encourages collaboration, shared responsibility, and thoughtful decision-making—rather than passive or symbolic participation.
This approach is distinct from HBCUvc’s core education and career-access programs. Historically, our work has focused on preparing individuals to enter venture ecosystems. This pilot tests whether those same communities are ready to act as coordinated capital participants when provided with the right scaffolding.
Importantly, this is not a fund launch—it is an experiment in systems design. The innovation lies in testing whether community-based angel coordination, anchored by trusted Black fund managers, can safely mobilize sidelined capital and concentrate economic power in a way that is both scalable and mission-aligned.

label.plain: Describe the intended use of funds should you receive Catalytic Funding. What specific activities, assets, investments, or resources will this investment enable?

field.label: Describe the intended use of funds should you receive Catalytic Funding. What specific activities, assets, investments, or resources will this investment enable?
field.value:
If awarded Catalytic Funding, the $25,000 will be used exclusively for organizational capacity-building to design, implement, and evaluate the angel co-investment coordination pilot. These funds will not be used for direct investment into companies.
Specifically, the funding will support: • Staff time to design and manage the pilot, including angel onboarding, partner coordination, and deal execution workflows • Legal, compliance, and administrative infrastructure required to coordinate investments responsibly alongside external fund managers • Development of internal systems and documentation to support angel communication, commitment tracking, and capital coordination • Pilot evaluation and learning, including feedback from angels, fund managers, and founders
This investment enables HBCUvc to test a new model without diverting resources from our core education programs. As a small organization, we cannot responsibly experiment with capital coordination without dedicated capacity support.
Echoing Green’s catalytic funding allows us to answer a critical question: can we responsibly coordinate capital from a community of new investors in a way that expands access, builds trust, and concentrates economic power—without overextending organizational capacity?

label.plain: Describe what success looks like for this project. If the project is successful, how will your organization be better positioned for growth?

field.label: Describe what success looks like for this project. If the project is successful, how will your organization be better positioned for growth?
field.value:
Success for this project means validating a new growth pathway for HBCUvc—one that expands our role from talent development into coordinated capital activation, while remaining disciplined and mission-aligned.
In the short term, success includes successfully convening a cohort of approximately 30 accredited HBCU alumni angels, coordinating up to three investments alongside trusted Black fund managers, and demonstrating that community-based capital can move off the sidelines when supported by professional leadership, shared conviction, and low-risk entry points.
More importantly, success positions HBCUvc for long-term growth in three key ways.
First, it establishes a repeatable model for engaging accredited investors beyond education—deepening alumni engagement and expanding our value proposition from access to action. Second, it creates a credible foundation for building a future capital platform or fund, informed by real operational data rather than assumption. Third, it opens a new pathway toward financial sustainability by testing whether capital coordination can eventually support a durable revenue and impact engine for the organization.
If the pilot is successful, HBCUvc will be equipped to pursue larger-scale capital strategies with confidence—whether by raising a larger fund, formalizing the platform, or partnering with aligned institutions—without compromising our core programs.
Success, ultimately, means clarity: a validated path for growth that allows HBCUvc to responsibly scale its impact, concentrate economic power within its community, and sustain its work over the long term.

label.plain: What do you hope to learn through implementing this project, and how will those learnings inform your longer-term growth strategy?

field.label: What do you hope to learn through implementing this project, and how will those learnings inform your longer-term growth strategy?
field.value:
Through this pilot, HBCUvc seeks to generate practical, decision-shaping insights about whether coordinated angel investing can serve as a viable growth pathway for the organization and a meaningful mechanism for moving sidelined capital into undercapitalized communities.
First, we aim to learn whether accredited HBCU alumni angels will consistently deploy capital when investments are led by trusted Black fund managers and structured for collective participation. This includes understanding what levels of trust, facilitation, and communication are required to move investors from interest to action.
Second, we will assess the operational demands of coordinating community-based capital. We seek to understand the true organizational capacity required—staff time, legal infrastructure, governance, and systems—to run this model responsibly without compromising our core education programs.
Third, we want to learn how this model is experienced by founders and fund managers. We will evaluate whether coordinated angel participation adds value, reduces friction, and strengthens alignment—or whether it introduces unintended complexity at the pre-seed stage.
Finally, we will explore the strategic sustainability of this approach. Can capital coordination become a repeatable platform or capital engine that supports HBCUvc’s long-term growth and financial resilience? Or should it remain a limited, complementary function within our broader ecosystem?
These learnings will directly inform HBCUvc’s 2027 strategy. Rather than scaling prematurely, we will use evidence from this pilot to determine whether to expand, refine, partner, or sunset the model—ensuring that future growth is disciplined, mission-aligned, and grounded in real-world performance rather than aspiration.

label.plain: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

field.label: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

label.plain: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

field.label: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.
field.value:
Validated product–market fit for smallholder agriculture by delivering bundled services such as inputs, advisory, financing, and market access to over 23,000 smallholder-farmers across Nigeria.
Demonstrated measurable impact at scale, achieving an average 40% increase in yields and 50% increase in farmer incomes, confirming the effectiveness of our model.
Distributed over 20,500 units of climate-smart agricultural inputs, improving productivity and strengthening food security across over 170 rural communities in Northern Nigeria
Launched solar-powered irrigation system initiatives to enable year-round production, reduce dependence on rainfall and diesel pumps, lower emissions, and increase climate resilience for smallholder-farmers.
Built a hybrid service delivery model integrating field operations, cooperatives, digital advisory, solar irrigation, and radio outreach, ensuring inclusion of farmers with or without internet access.
Developed the UBI digital platform as core infrastructure for farmer registration, verification, loan management, advisory services, transactional services and data collection which supports data-driven scaling and banking unbanked rural farmers.
Established over 200 trusted cooperative and community networks, particularly among women and youth, enabling aggregation, irrigation management, peer learning, and collective market access.
Evolved into an integrated food-systems enterprise, expanding into value addition (rice, soybean, cowpea), nutrition-focused products.
Positioned for national and regional scale, with clear multi-state expansion plans, hybrid operations, and sustainable revenue pathways.

label.plain: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:

field.label: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:
field.value: RacismoMX works to dismantle the systems that sustain racism in Mexico and Latin America. We make racism visible where it has long been denied, transforming lived experience into public dialogue, institutional accountability, and structural change. Through an anti-racist, human-rights, and intersectional approach, we combine education, research, strategic advocacy, and legal action in partnership with communities, governments, and the private sector. Our vision is a region where historically racialized people are recognized as rights-holders and leaders, diversity is actively valued, and justice and equality are embedded in policies, institutions, and cultural norms.

label.plain: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.

field.label: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.
field.value:
RacismoMX advances systems change to dismantle structural racism in Mexico through youth leadership, research, strategic litigation, public policy advocacy, and cross-sector collaboration. Its work centers Indigenous, Afro-descendant, migrant, and other racialized communities through an intersectional, human-rights-based approach.
At the core of RacismoMX’s model is leadership development. The Young Anti-Racist Leadership Project (YALP) is an annual fellowship that equips emerging leaders in Mexico with anti-racist education, mentorship, and resources to implement community-based solutions. YALP has grown into a regional network of youth leaders driving long-term civic engagement, narrative change, and policy influence.
RacismoMX also leads large-scale, collaborative systems-change efforts. Through the Observatory of Racism in Mexico and Central America, the organization produces actionable research on migration, racial profiling, and environmental racism. This evidence informs the National Anti-Racist Agenda, a collective policy platform co-created with dozens of civil society organizations to advance institutional reforms at the local and national levels.
Legal accountability is a key pillar of impact. Through strategic litigation, RacismoMX supports emblematic cases of racial discrimination to set precedents and expose institutional racism. Its digital tool, Racistómetro, crowdsources reports of racial discrimination, generating data that strengthens advocacy and prevention strategies.
In parallel, RacismoMX works directly with the private sector. Through its DEI and Anti-Racism programs, including the Directory of Racialized Talent, the organization partners with companies to transform hiring practices and workplace culture, expanding access to employment opportunities for racialized professionals.
Together, these strategies position RacismoMX as a scalable, movement-building platform advancing equitable systems and inclusive leadership across the region.

label.plain: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

field.label: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:
field.value:
Since its founding, RacismoMX has become a reference in advancing anti-racist systems change in Mexico and has played a critical role in shifting public discourse by making racism visible as a structural problem—challenging long-standing narratives that deny its existence.
Through YALP, the organization has trained and mentored dozens of young leaders in Mexico, many of whom now lead community initiatives, influence public debate, and strengthen local and regional anti-racist movements.
At the systems level, RacismoMX has generated actionable evidence through its Observatory of Racism, producing research on racial profiling, migration, and environmental racism that has informed advocacy efforts, public policy discussions, and international human rights processes. The organization also led the development of a National Anti-Racist Agenda, co-created with over 60 civil society organizations, consolidating 20 strong policy proposals presented to legislative bodies and decision-makers.
Through strategic litigation and legal accompaniment, RacismoMX has supported more than 20 emblematic cases of racial discrimination, contributing to legal recognition of racism and setting important precedents for accountability. Also, RacismoMX has promoted the Anti-racist Corporate Agreement with more than 30 companies signing it, partnering with companies to advance DEI and anti-racist practices.
Finally, RacismoMX’s impact has also reached the international stage. Its Director, José A. Aguilar, serves as a member of the Group of Independent Eminent Experts on the Durban Declaration, advising the United Nations on the implementation of global commitments to combat racism, xenophobia, and related intolerance. This role reflects the organization’s growing influence in shaping both national and global anti-racist policy agendas.

label.plain: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

field.label: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

label.plain: Describe the long-term vision for your work and how, at scale, your work will help create a world free from systemic oppression.

field.label: Describe the long-term vision for your work and how, at scale, your work will help create a world free from systemic oppression.
field.value:
RacismoMX envisions a future in which anti-racism is not a marginal intervention, but a foundational principle shaping institutions, economies, and cultural narratives across Mexico and Latin America. Our long-term vision is to help build societies where systemic oppression—rooted in racism, colonial legacies, and intersecting forms of discrimination—is actively dismantled and replaced by systems grounded in justice, equity, and collective dignity.
At scale, RacismoMX works to transform how power operates. By investing in youth leadership, we cultivate generations of leaders from historically excluded communities who are equipped to influence policy, reshape public discourse, and design solutions rooted in lived experience. Through research and data generation, we make racism visible, measurable, and actionable—providing the evidence needed to challenge denial, inform public policy, and hold institutions accountable.
Our vision recognizes that lasting change requires structural alignment across sectors. By combining strategic litigation, policy agendas, and partnerships with government and the private sector, RacismoMX advances institutional reforms that redistribute opportunity, protect rights, and prevent discrimination before it occurs. Our work with companies on DEI embeds anti-racist practices into economic systems, expanding access to dignified employment and shifting norms within influential institutions.
Ultimately, RacismoMX contributes to a world free from systemic oppression by helping move societies from awareness to action, from isolated interventions to coordinated systems change. We imagine a future where racial justice is sustained by strong institutions, inclusive leadership, and a shared commitment to collective liberation—where equality is not aspirational, but structural and enduring.

label.plain: Describe the specific initiatives, projects, or investments you intend to make in the next year that move you toward your long-term vision for systemic change.

field.label: Describe the specific initiatives, projects, or investments you intend to make in the next year that move you toward your long-term vision for systemic change.
field.value:
Over the next year, RacismoMX will pilot a lending circles initiative to combat financial exclusion mainly affecting migrant communities in Mexico. More and more, migrants are looking to stay in Mexico and they are routinely denied access to open accounts and stable employment not because of financial risk, but because formal financial systems exclude those without documentation, formal contracts, or credit histories.
This initiative will formalize long-standing cultural practices of community saving by establishing structured, trust-based lending circles (known as “tandas” in Mexico). In our tandas, participants will collectively save and access rotating capital while having their payments reported to credit reporting agencies, allowing migrants without prior credit histories to begin building a formal credit score.
In this first year, RacismoMX will co-design and implement pilot tandas with fellow organizations dedicated to migrant rights, ensuring community governance, transparency, and accountability. To strengthen long-term impact, the organization will also offer financial education workshops, developed in partnership with financial institutions and experts. These workshops will focus on financial rights, savings, and debt prevention—equipping participants with the knowledge to fully leverage their potential access to formal banking.
Participants will gain immediate capital to meet basic needs while simultaneously building pathways to improved employment opportunities and fairer interest rates. This initiative advances RacismoMX’s long-term vision for systemic change by directly intervening in an exclusionary economic system and testing a scalable, anti-racist model of financial inclusion—one that redefines creditworthiness through collective trust, shared responsibility, and community-led wealth building.

label.plain: Catalytic Funding prioritizes applications that support organizations to test new and unproven ideas, models, or methods. Please describe how your proposed work is innovative and distinct from your core operating model.

field.label: Catalytic Funding prioritizes applications that support organizations to test new and unproven ideas, models, or methods.  Please describe how your proposed work is innovative and distinct from your core operating model.
field.value:
RacismoMX’s proposed learning circles initiative or tandas is an innovative and viable expansion of its work because it builds directly on the trust the organization has cultivated over years of engagement with historically racialized communities—particularly migrants who are routinely excluded from formal financial systems. RacismoMX’s longstanding presence through education, legal accompaniment, research, and advocacy has positioned it as a credible and accountable actor within these communities, creating the social capital necessary to pilot a trust-based financial model.
The initiative responds to a core driver of systemic oppression: economic inequality as a direct consequence of structural racism. In Mexico, migrants face barriers to banking, employment, and credit, not due to lack of financial responsibility, but because of exclusionary criteria such as documentation status, formal employment, or credit history. This project intervenes directly in that system by formalizing culturally rooted tandas—a collective savings practice already used by migrant communities—and linking them to formal credit reporting agencies.
What makes this initiative distinct from RacismoMX’s core operating model is its shift from advocacy and accountability toward direct economic experimentation. Rather than only challenging exclusionary systems from the outside, RacismoMX is testing whether community-based financial practices can be translated into recognized financial capital, allowing migrants to build credit, access housing, improve employment prospects, and secure fairer interest rates.
Aligned with Echoing Green’s Catalytic Funding goals, this initiative is intentionally experimental and learning-oriented. It tests a new method for closing racialized economic gaps by redefining creditworthiness through collective trust and mutual responsibility.

label.plain: Describe the intended use of funds should you receive Catalytic Funding. What specific activities, assets, investments, or resources will this investment enable?

field.label: Describe the intended use of funds should you receive Catalytic Funding. What specific activities, assets, investments, or resources will this investment enable?
field.value:
Catalytic Funding will enable the design, testing, and validation of this innovative lending circles model that addresses financial exclusion among migrants in Mexico. Funds will be used to build the critical infrastructure required to pilot this initiative responsibly, securely, and at learning scale.
A primary use of funds will be IT development for a secure digital platform to manage lending circles. This includes participant onboarding, contribution tracking, payment schedules, and data reporting mechanisms that allow on-time payments to be recognized by credit reporting agencies. This platform is essential to transforming informal community savings into a pathway toward formal credit access.
Catalytic Funding will also support legal advisory services to ensure compliance with financial regulations, data protection standards, and migrant rights frameworks. Legal expertise will guide the design of agreements, reporting processes, and safeguards that protect participants.
Investment in human capital is another core component. Funds will support staff capacity to negotiate partnerships with financial institutions and credit bureaus, as well as to coordinate community engagement, pilot implementation, and financial education workshops delivered alongside the tandas.
Finally, a portion of the funding will establish a backup cash reserve to stabilize the pilot. Although research shows that tandas have a 99% of repayment rate, this reserve will allow RacismoMX to intervene when a participant temporarily cannot meet a payment, protecting the collective integrity of the lending circle.
Together, these investments enable RacismoMX to test an unproven but promising model, generate learning, and lay the foundation for scalable, anti-racist financial inclusion.

label.plain: Describe what success looks like for this project. If the project is successful, how will your organization be better positioned for growth?

field.label: Describe what success looks like for this project. If the project is successful, how will your organization be better positioned for growth?
field.value:
Success for this project means demonstrating that migrants’ existing economic activity—already taking place through informal work and community saving—can be safely formalized and recognized by the financial system without compromising dignity, trust, or rights.
In practical terms, success looks like migrant participants building verifiable credit histories through lending circles, gaining increased financial literacy, and successfully entering the formal economy. Participants are able to open bank accounts, access fair credit products, improve employment prospects, and reduce reliance on predatory lending. Financial education workshops strengthen migrants’ understanding of savings, debt, and financial rights, enabling informed and confident engagement with financial institutions.
At the systems level, success means that banks and financial institutions recognize migrants as viable clients. Through demonstrated repayment data, financial institutions begin offering tailored products—such as savings accounts, low-interest credit, and eventually housing loans—designed for migrant realities. In the strongest outcome, banks move beyond passive inclusion to become advocates for migrants, using evidence from the pilot to push for regulatory flexibility and inclusive financial policies that expand access rather than restrict it.
RacismoMX will be better positioned for growth in three key ways. First, it will have validated a scalable, financial inclusion model in Mexico grounded in community trust and data. Second, it will strengthen its role as a bridge between marginalized communities and powerful institutions, expanding cross-sector partnerships. Finally, RacismoMX will gain the evidence and credibility needed to replicate the model nationally and regionally, positioning the organization as a leader in economic justice for migrants and other racialized communities.

label.plain: What do you hope to learn through implementing this project, and how will those learnings inform your longer-term growth strategy?

field.label: What do you hope to learn through implementing this project, and how will those learnings inform your longer-term growth strategy?
field.value:
Through implementing this initiative, RacismoMX aims to generate critical learning that will reshape both its practice and long-term growth strategy. First, the project will deepen RacismoMX’s understanding of how to engage migrant communities not as passive recipients of charity, but as economic actors with agency, intelligence, and dignity. By co-designing lending circles with participants, the organization will learn how trust, collective responsibility, and community governance function in real-world financial decision-making.
Second, RacismoMX will gain practical insight into the demand and risk profile of community-based financial products among migrants. This includes understanding repayment behaviors, participation dynamics, risk mitigation needs, and the conditions under which lending circles are most effective and sustainable. These learnings will inform whether and how the model can be responsibly scaled.
Third, the initiative will generate technical knowledge on designing and building digital infrastructure capable of managing lending circles and producing reliable data for credit reporting agencies. This includes learning what data standards, reporting mechanisms, and safeguards are required to translate informal economic activity into formally recognized credit histories.
Finally, RacismoMX will learn what requirements, incentives, and evidence financial institutions need in order to include migrants as a viable and valuable client group. This knowledge will strengthen the organization’s ability to negotiate partnerships, influence product design, and advocate for regulatory change.
Together, these learnings will position RacismoMX to grow as a systems-change organization—one capable of replicating the model, influencing inclusive finance policy, and expanding its impact at the intersection of racial justice and economic inclusion.

label.plain: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:

field.label: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:
field.value: HJI's mission is to address systemic health inequities and racial health injustice. Our vision is a health sector that is fair, just, transparent, and accountable where everyone has equitable and affordable access to healthcare and life saving technologies (medicines). We focus on bringing the voices of the global majority into decision-making processes; and enabling fair and accountable domestic and international public health systems - by showing the intersection between health justice, racial and gender inequity, and climate injustice.

label.plain: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.

field.label: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.
field.value: HJI advances its mission and vision through a range of strategic activities that center equity, transparency, and accountability. HJI convenes diverse coalitions both locally and abroad and builds alliances that amplify marginalised voices and challenges entrenched power structures in health governance. Through evidence-based advocacy, HJI campaigns for universal healthcare as evidenced by the organisation’s research and continued advocacy in critiquing and shaping South Africa’s National Health Insurance plans which is meant to secure UHC; advocating for marginalised groups and the Global South to be prioritised in vaccine rollout programs during the pandemic; advocating for an end to health xenophobia in South Africa’s public healthcare system inter alia. HJI has successfully litigated for transparency in pandemic procurement contracts and raised awareness of systemic inequities such as price secrecy which hinder equitable access. HJI has also supported patent challenges to TB drugs and co-lead coalitions demanding governments break IP barriers that restrict access to life saving HIV prevention and cystic fibrosis treatments, as part of our work in dismantling intellectual property barriers that restrict access. HJI engages directly with patient groups, governments, parliament, and multi-national institutions, submitting evidence driven recommendations, mobilising public campaigns, and holding decision-makers accountable for upholding human rights obligations. This has included supporting the South African government in its global negotiations for a TRIPS waiver during the pandemic; for equitable health programmes and medicine access that prioritise those in need first, not those who are privileged and rich- addressing systemic barriers and exclusion from health services.

label.plain: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

field.label: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:
field.value:
In 5.5 years, we have become a leading voice on global health equity for the Global South, sought out for our thought leadership. We published in prominent journals; write for major publications, and called on by international media houses, journalists, civil society, funders, government officials, academia and the private sector to share our ideas on how to generate efforts to overcome health inequity. HJI’s litigation for transparency in vaccine procurement exposed inequitable practices and set global precedent for public accountability. By mobilising coalitions across the Global South, HJI amplified marginalised and key population voices. HJI’s advocacy/research (with partners) contributed to life-saving breakthroughs such as the seminal withdrawal by a big pharma company of its restrictive patent of a key TB medicine, opening the way for affordable generics in hundreds of LMICs. HJI shaped debates on universal healthcare and equitable access to medicines through a feminist and decolonial lens, linking health access to inequality. Through accessible communications, public campaigns, trainings, strategic convenings -HJI has transformed complex policy issues into accessible information. We build intersectional movements that challenge profiteering and demand health justice by connecting aligned stakeholders.
We have conducted over 350 media interviews; published articles in various outlets, educating the public on health inequity issues; hosted multiple webinars; spoken at over 50 conferences/lectures and written over 40 op-eds. We were the first Global South NGO to publish a global south led Compendium featuring critical analysis of pandemic developments with lessons for future health crisis management for the Global South.

label.plain: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

field.label: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

label.plain: Describe the long-term vision for your work and how, at scale, your work will help create a world free from systemic oppression.

field.label: Describe the long-term vision for your work and how, at scale, your work will help create a world free from systemic oppression.
field.value:
HJI plans to deepen its role as a catalyst for systemic reform by strengthening civil society’s capacity to defend equity in healthcare often against powerful special interest groups that have the resources to bully governments into maintaining the status quo of profit over people.
At a time when governments and international organisations are cutting back on health funding pledges and imposing exclusionary limits, HJI works to ensure that marginalized communities are not left behind. The past year has underscored the urgency of this work, and HJI’s vision is to confront the erosion in global funding with accountability and solidarity.
At home, HJI demands immediate consequences when government officials fail in their duties and resist the weakening of the public health system. Central to our work is securing affordability and access to medicines, challenging restrictive patent laws because it enables monopolies and in turn, high prices.
Globally, we continue linking health justice to broader struggles for justice and equality, advocating for universal health coverage, and working with our vast network of partners and allies to strengthen governance structures that guarantee access. Our work is premised on addressing the structural and commercial determinants of ill health, focusing on the Intellectual Property system and inequity in global Research & Development pipelines that create barriers to access for marginalised populations. By disrupting monopolies, exposing hypocrisy and profiteering, and centering equity, our long-term vision is creating a world where health systems serve all people - and where privilege is not a proxy for timely access.

label.plain: Describe the specific initiatives, projects, or investments you intend to make in the next year that move you toward your long-term vision for systemic change.

field.label: Describe the specific initiatives, projects, or investments you intend to make in the next year that move you toward your long-term vision for systemic change.
field.value:
In the coming year, HJI will advance projects designed to strengthen equity, accountability, and systemic reform in health governance. These projects include ongoing research, advocacy, and litigation support for civil society groups striving to make the NHI in South Africa a practical pathway to universal healthcare for all users including migrants and refugees.
HJI will also convene workshops and coalition meetings to prepare parliamentary submissions on the long-awaited patent law reform process, ensuring that restrictive intellectual property practices are challenged through democratic and creative processes while also pursuing an on-going legal case on this issue. At a regulatory level, HJI will support bodies that hold multinational corporations accountable for anti-trust market conduct. This includes advocacy around the Competition Commission's on-going investigation into anti-competitive practices in the insulin pen market by manufacturers Novo Nordisk and Sanofi; supporting the South African Cystic Fibrosis Association (SACFA) push for the reopening of the critical regulatory investigation into Vertex’s price gouging of a lifesaving cystic fibrosis treatment, Trikafta for adults and children with CF.
Globally, HJI will continue working with partners to advocate and negotiate for the scaled-up and equitable introduction of a new revolutionary HIV prevention tool, lenacapavir, in low-and-middle-income countries and in/for countries excluded from timely access by: Gilead’s indefensible market practices and the US/Trump administrations irrational HIV funding policy (cuts and exclusions) while pushing for compulsory licensing and the market entry of more affordable generics. to ensure that every person on need of HIV prevention, can access it across the Global South.

label.plain: Catalytic Funding prioritizes applications that support organizations to test new and unproven ideas, models, or methods. Please describe how your proposed work is innovative and distinct from your core operating model.

field.label: Catalytic Funding prioritizes applications that support organizations to test new and unproven ideas, models, or methods.  Please describe how your proposed work is innovative and distinct from your core operating model.
field.value:
HJI wants to advance an innovative model that leverages the research capacity of interns and fellows and drive systemic patent law reform 30 years after democracy via the ''Government of National Unity'' with multi-party representation in Parliament (first since 1994). The GNU (and US/EU)will decide the fate of our country's future patent laws (this is momentous).
By prioritising young, black, female lawyers, a voice underrepresented in the niche, intellectual property field which has historically been dominated by older white men in SA, HJI seeks to 1.disrupt entrenched exclusion and bring fresh perspectives to an IP system rooted in racism and colonialism for too long; 2.prepare and submit evidence based research with best practice case studies to effectively support or re-write our apartheid era IP Laws. This differs from HJI’s core model which relied on mobilisation and then litigation to effect policy change because up until last year, Parliament WAS dominated by a single political party. It no longer is.
The GNU’s diverse political composition now gives us a chance, as a CSO, to test whether the legislature (key arm of government) can indeed become a force for change-challenging pharmaceutical monopolies. This will serve as a case study in whether CSOs can build consensus across political divides to advance a policy already set in motion by a previous political administration. The model could achieve dual impact by combining progressive, systemic law reform with capacity-building to disrupt IP law through parliamentary reform-while cultivating a new generation of social justice-driven human rights lawyers.

label.plain: Describe the intended use of funds should you receive Catalytic Funding. What specific activities, assets, investments, or resources will this investment enable?

field.label: Describe the intended use of funds should you receive Catalytic Funding. What specific activities, assets, investments, or resources will this investment enable?
field.value:
The funds will be used to provide compensation for interns and dedicated research fellows to ensure sustained engagement as HJI develops a pipeline of women led IP expertise. It will also support the production of accessible briefs, reports, and submissions to the relevant parliamentary committee and key political parties; the use of local and global experts in supporting the in-depth legal and policy research on patent law reform, evergreening, and pharmaceutical abuse where necessary.
HJI will also organise training sessions for interns and fellows, and coalition partners on IP law, parliamentary processes, and advocacy to strengthen collective knowledge. HJI will host dialogues and strategic meetings with key policymakers and civil society allies to build consensus across political divides and amplify the perspectives and evidence generated by interns and fellows. Some funding will be put into developing accessible materials to mobilise public support for HJI’s recommendations while highlighting the GNU parties’ accountability gaps and the immense industry and foreign government pressure (Trump) that will be employed to delay reform that has taken 30 years to materialise. In addition, the funding will enable us to provide evidence of likely trade pressure that will be exerted by both the US and EU to prevent or delay IP reforms to benefit EU/US based pharma companies.

label.plain: Describe what success looks like for this project. If the project is successful, how will your organization be better positioned for growth?

field.label: Describe what success looks like for this project. If the project is successful, how will your organization be better positioned for growth?
field.value:
Success: South Africa has a new IP and Patent law that prioritises patients and the public interest and includes the right of patients to oppose a patent BEFORE it is granted; simplifies state action measures against patent abuse in health emergencies, without sanctions from foreign governments/trade ambassadors.
If successful, HJI’s interns and fellows will place the organisation in a stronger position for long-term growth and systemic impact: By embedding young, black, female lawyers and researchers into public parliamentary processes, HJI will further establish itself as a credible source of expertise in legislative reform. This will expand HJI’s influence beyond mobilisation and litigation into shaping law directly, positioning the organisation as a trusted partner for parliament, civil society, and regulatory bodies that prioritise diversity too.
The project will strengthen HJI’s research capacity, enabling the organisation to produce high-quality submissions, policy briefs, and evidence by black women lawyers, that can withstand industry pressure and political resistance – ultimately shaping a new law. By cultivating and encouraging a new generation of IP lawyers, HJI ensures sustainability and continuity, building a pipeline of leaders who can carry its mission forward. Success will demonstrate that civil society can use parliamentary processes to challenge monopolies (evergreening/patent abuse) creating a replicable model for other movements – or not. It will publicly highlight different political parties' positions on IP reform.
Growth will come not only from policy wins, but from the ability to combine systemic reform with capacity-building, and ensuring equity and accountability remain central to medicine access.

label.plain: What do you hope to learn through implementing this project, and how will those learnings inform your longer-term growth strategy?

field.label: What do you hope to learn through implementing this project, and how will those learnings inform your longer-term growth strategy?
field.value:
HJI will gain critical insights into how a GNU led parliamentary process can be leveraged by civil society; translate rigorous research into practical advocacy tools that resonate across the political divide. This will deepen HJI and the publics understanding of coalition dynamics within the GNU, revealing both opportunities for consensus and likely barriers posed by vested interests and financial dependencies (party political funders).
HJI will learn how to balance research, network building (partners), litigation and political mobilisation with parliamentary engagement, refining a hybrid model that strengthens our capacity to hold ''government'' accountable while building pathways for law reform. The project will also highlight the effectiveness of investing in underrepresented gendered voices, showing how new perspectives and experiences from other Global South countries can challenge IP maximalist approaches and colonial legacies embedded in IP law-expanding the field of health justice advocacy.
These learnings will inform HJI’s longer-term growth strategy by embedding research capacity led not by permanent staff, but by interns and fellows, into our core operations, ideally strengthening partnerships with parliamentary committees and regulatory bodies, and ensuring HJI's leadership pipelines are diverse and resilient.
HJI can scale law reform in other areas by replicating the strategy across other policy areas, and sustain systemic change rooted in equity and accountability. More than anything, if successful and the law is changed, it could become the single biggest reason in 50 years time, to enable all patients to access life- saving medication at an affordable price, in a timely, equitable manner.

label.plain: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:

field.label: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:
field.value: Our mission is to empower smallholder farmers with affordable precision agriculture tools that replace guesswork with evidence-based decisions. At the same time, our vision is a future where every farmer can farm profitably, sustainably, and with confidence. Operating in rural Kenyan communities, where the average annual income is just $337, we deploy low-cost soil sensors and SMS-based advisory services to deliver personalized crop and fertilizer recommendations within minutes. By democratizing access to real-time agricultural intelligence, we aim to increase yields, raise incomes, strengthen climate resilience, and contribute to long-term food security across Kenya and the wider African continent.

label.plain: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.

field.label: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.
field.value: UjuziKilimo provides a simple, fast, and affordable way for smallholder farmers to monitor and improve soil fertility. We deploy proprietary, low-cost soil sensor technology that measures key parameters, including soil moisture, pH, nutrient levels (nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium), electrical conductivity (EC), and geolocation. Unlike traditional soil testing methods, our technology does not rely on pre-existing soil maps, making it universally applicable across diverse farming regions. Using a highly personalized, farmer-centered approach; akin to having an expert agronomist at one’s fingertips, sensor data is transmitted to our cloud platform and analyzed in real time. Within minutes, farmers receive tailored SMS recommendations on crop selection, fertilizer application, and soil management optimized for their specific conditions and target crops. To scale impact and create local livelihoods, UjuziKilimo distributes sensors to trained youth and women who operate micro-enterprises, offering soil monitoring as a service to farmers. Revenue generated is shared between the agents and UjuziKilimo, ensuring sustainability, local ownership, and inclusive economic empowerment.

label.plain: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

field.label: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

label.plain: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

field.label: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.
field.value: Since completing the fellowship, UjuziKilimo has achieved significant scale and impact across East Africa. To date, we have reached more than 100,000 smallholder farmers, enabling them to analyze their soil quality and make evidence-based farming decisions. By following the personalized recommendations delivered through our platform, farmers have been able to triple their crop yields. This productivity gain has translated into meaningful income growth and poverty reduction. In Kenya, where the average annual household income for smallholder farmers is approximately $537, tripling yields has increased average incomes to about $1,611 per year. This income growth has directly improved household food security and contributed to reducing hunger at the community level. Beyond income, the increased earnings have enabled farming households to invest in better healthcare, education, and farm inputs, leading to improved livelihoods and long-term resilience. The impact has been particularly strong for women, who make up the majority of smallholder farmers, helping to narrow gender inequality through higher incomes and greater economic agency.
