label.plain: How do you plan to increase the financial sustainability of your work through earned revenue? What product or service do you plan to sell, to whom, and how will you operationalize this work within your organization?

field.label: How do you plan to increase the financial sustainability of your work through earned revenue? What product or service do you plan to sell, to whom, and how will you operationalize this work within your organization?
field.value: We plan to increase the financial sustainability of our work by building a diversified earned-revenue model anchored in affordable, high-demand soil intelligence services for smallholder farmers and institutional partners. Our primary revenue stream comes from selling soil testing services directly to farmers through a network of trained field agents. Farmers pay $15 per soil test, which includes on-site soil analysis and personalized SMS-based agronomic recommendations. To incentivize quality service delivery and local entrepreneurship, revenues from each test are shared on a 60:40 basis between UjuziKilimo and the agents. This model creates recurring income for the organization while generating livelihoods for youth and women operating as last-mile service providers. In addition to pay-per-test services, we sell our soil sensing devices to farmer groups, development partners, NGOs, and county governments. These institutional customers pay an upfront down payment of $1,200 per device, followed by a monthly subscription fee of $300 for unlimited use of the sensor across farmers within their networks. This model enables partners to scale soil testing rapidly within their programs while providing UjuziKilimo with predictable, recurring revenue. Operationally, UjuziKilimo manages device manufacturing, quality control, data analytics, and the digital advisory platform, while agents and partners handle field deployment and farmer engagement. Revenue from services and device subscriptions is reinvested into technology improvement, agent training, and geographic expansion, ensuring long-term financial sustainability while maintaining affordability for smallholder farmers.

label.plain: Tell us more about your target market, who are they, how big is the market and what problem does your offering solve for them

field.label: Tell us more about your target market, who are they, how big is the market and what problem does your offering solve for them
field.value: Our target market consists primarily of small- to medium-scale farmers who face persistent challenges in increasing crop yields due to limited access to reliable soil and agronomic information. There are an estimated 5–6 million smallholder farmers in Kenya, most of whom rely on rain-fed agriculture, use fertilizers inefficiently, and make farming decisions based on guesswork rather than data. Despite these constraints, the majority of these farmers have access to basic mobile phones, creating a strong foundation for digital, SMS-based advisory solutions. Across Sub-Saharan Africa, there are approximately 51.3 million farms, representing a large and underserved market. Using an average industry price of $10–15 per soil test, this translates into a market opportunity exceeding $500 million annually. Africa as a whole is home to more than 300 million smallholder farmers who produce nearly 80% of the continent’s food, yet operate at only about 30% of their productive potential. Soil nutrient depletion alone results in average losses of 40 kilograms of macronutrients per hectare each year, equivalent to an estimated US$5 billion in lost fertilizer value annually. UjuziKilimo addresses these challenges by providing fast, affordable, and localized soil intelligence that enables farmers to make informed decisions. Our model is already demonstrating traction. We currently work with 50 active field agents who serve approximately 1,000 farmers annually through soil testing and personalized recommendations. This agent-led, data-driven approach solves the core problem of information asymmetry, helping farmers increase yields, reduce input waste, improve incomes, and build resilience in the face of climate variability.

label.plain: What are the main variable costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., materials, labor costs, delivery, etc.)?

field.label: What are the main variable costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., materials, labor costs, delivery, etc.)?
field.value: The main variable costs associated with operating this revenue stream are closely tied to service delivery, agent engagement, and technology usage. Field agent compensation is the highest variable cost. For each soil test sold to farmers, 40% of the $15 service fee is paid to the field agent who conducts the test, covers local transport, and engages the farmer. This cost scales directly with the number of farmers served and ensures strong incentives for quality service delivery. Our Technology and data processing costs also scale with usage. These include cloud server hosting, data storage, analytics processing, and SMS delivery fees for sending personalized recommendations to farmers. As the number of soil tests increases, messaging and server costs rise proportionally. Device maintenance and replacement are also variable costs. Sensors used in the field require calibration, repairs, and occasional replacement due to wear and tear or environmental damage. These costs increase with higher deployment volumes and geographic spread. Finally, training and quality assurance costs vary with scale. As new agents are onboarded or existing agents expand coverage, UjuziKilimo incurs variable costs related to training sessions, refresher courses, and performance monitoring. Together, these variable costs scale in line with revenue growth, allowing the model to maintain flexibility while supporting high-quality, reliable service delivery to smallholder farmers.

label.plain: What are the main fixed costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., equipment, pro-rata salaries, rent etc.)?

field.label: What are the main fixed costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., equipment, pro-rata salaries, rent etc.)?
field.value: The main fixed costs for operating UjuziKilimo remain relatively constant regardless of the number of farmers served. These include equipment and infrastructure costs, such as the initial production of soil sensors, computers, and mobile devices necessary for managing data collection, analysis, and SMS delivery. Salaries for core staff, including program managers, data analysts, IT personnel, and administrative staff, are fixed costs that support operations, agent coordination, and technology maintenance. Office rent and utilities represent another fixed expense, providing workspace for staff, storage for devices, and coordination of field activities. Software licenses and platform subscriptions for cloud services, data analytics tools, and SMS gateways also constitute fixed costs, as these are ongoing expenses that do not fluctuate directly with the number of farmers served. Additionally, marketing and capacity-building materials such as training manuals, printed guides, and branding materials for agent programs are largely fixed, as they are produced upfront to support operations across multiple farming cycles. Collectively, these fixed costs establish the operational backbone of UjuziKilimo, ensuring consistent s

label.plain: How do you plan to price your product or service? What factors informed your pricing strategy?

field.label: How do you plan to price your product or service? What factors informed your pricing strategy?
field.value: Our pricing strategy is designed to balance affordability for smallholder farmers, incentives for field agents, and financial sustainability for UjuziKilimo. Our core soil testing service is priced at $15 per test, a rate that is accessible to most small- to medium-scale farmers while covering operational costs. Of this fee, 40% is paid directly to field agents as compensation for conducting tests, engaging farmers, and covering local transport, while an additional 5% is allocated to service delivery costs, including logistics and minor consumables. For institutional customers such as development partners, farmer groups, and county governments, we sell our soil sensing devices at $3,000 each. These devices cost $1,000 to manufacture, allowing for a significant margin to support UjuziKilimo operations and future innovation. Institutional customers make a $1,200 down payment and pay a monthly subscription fee of $300 for unlimited use of the device across farmers in their networks. This pricing structure ensures predictable, recurring revenue while enabling large-scale deployment. Factors informing our pricing strategy include the economic realities of smallholder farmers, the need to incentivize agents through a meaningful revenue share, the cost of manufacturing and maintaining high-quality sensors, and the value delivered to institutional partners who can scale soil testing across multiple farmers. By combining affordable pay-per-use services with subscription-based institutional sales, our pricing model supports growth, sustainability, and impact at scale.

label.plain: What upfront investments are needed to deliver this product or service (e.g., staff, technology, infrastructure, etc.)?

field.label: What upfront investments are needed to deliver this product or service (e.g., staff, technology, infrastructure, etc.)?
field.value: Delivering our soil testing products and services at scale requires several upfront investments across technology, human resources, and infrastructure. A major upfront cost is device manufacturing. Over the next 12 months, we plan to manufacture an additional 100 proprietary soil testing devices for $800 per device, resulting in a total investment of $80,000. These devices will be deployed through field agents and institutional partners to support expanded service delivery. Human capital investments are also critical. We will onboard and train 50 new field agents, primarily youth and women, for $200 per agent, totaling $10,000. This training covers sensor usage, data collection protocols, farmer engagement, and basic agronomic interpretation to ensure high-quality service delivery. In addition, we will invest in core staff capacity, including marketing management, agronomy, data analytics, and technical support, with an estimated upfront allocation of $50,000 in pro-rata salaries to manage expanded operations and agent coordination. Our technology and platform costs include cloud server costs, data analytics infrastructure, SMS and data delivery systems, and ongoing software development to support increased data volumes. This investment will support manufacturing, workforce expansion, and the operational infrastructure required to deliver our soil testing services effectively at scale.

label.plain: What is your projected revenue from this stream within the next 12 months?

field.label: What is your projected revenue from this stream within the next 12 months?
field.value: Within the next 12 months, we project strong revenue growth from our soil testing services and institutional device sales. Over this period, we aim to deploy 50 new soil testing devices through trained field agents, significantly expanding our field presence. This expansion will enable us to serve approximately 50,000 farmers with paid soil testing services. At an average service price of $15 per farmer, this is expected to generate approximately $750,000 in revenue from soil testing services alone. In parallel, we plan to onboard five county governments as institutional partners. Each county government will procure 50 soil testing devices. Based on our pricing model, comprising an upfront down payment and monthly subscription fees, these partnerships are projected to generate approximately $240,000 in revenue over the 12 months. Combined, these two revenue streams are expected to generate total projected revenue of approximately $990,000 within the next year. This diversified revenue mix balances high-volume farmer-facing services with predictable, recurring institutional revenue, strengthening KilimoPlus’s financial sustainability while accelerating impact at scale.

label.plain: When do you expect to reach breakeven for this stream (i.e., when revenue covers all associated costs)?

field.label: When do you expect to reach breakeven for this stream (i.e., when revenue covers all associated costs)?
field.value: We expect to reach breakeven for this revenue stream within 13 months of scaled deployment. This projection is based on the rapid ramp-up of farmer-paid soil testing services and early institutional partnerships. Within the first 12 months, we project total revenues of approximately $990,000, driven by $750,000 from soil testing services and $240,000 from county government partnerships. The major upfront costs, particularly device manufacturing ($80,000 for 100 devices) and agent onboarding and training ($10,000 for 50 agents), are incurred early and amortized over multiple years of device usage. On the cost side, variable expenses such as agent commissions (40% of service revenue), SMS and cloud processing, logistics, and device maintenance scale proportionally with revenue, while fixed costs such as core staff salaries, technology infrastructure, and office operations remain relatively stable. As utilization of each device increases, the marginal cost per soil test declines significantly, improving unit economics. Based on these dynamics, we anticipate covering both operating expenses and upfront investments by the end of Year 1, with breakeven occurring around Month 13 under base-case assumptions. Beyond breakeven, incremental revenues are expected to generate positive cash flow, enabling reinvestment into additional devices, agent expansion, and geographic growth without reliance on grant funding.

label.plain: How will you test and validate the financial viability of this stream before scaling?

field.label: How will you test and validate the financial viability of this stream before scaling?
field.value: We will test and validate the financial viability of this revenue stream through a phased, data-driven approach before full-scale expansion. First, we will run controlled pilots with a limited number of new devices and field agents in selected counties, tracking unit economics at the device and agent level. This will allow us to validate key assumptions such as the average number of soil tests per device per month, farmer willingness to pay the $15 fee, agent productivity, and revenue per agent. Second, we will closely monitor cost-to-serve metrics, including agent commissions, logistics expenses, SMS and cloud processing costs, and device maintenance, to ensure that gross margins remain positive as volumes increase. We will test different deployment densities and service frequencies to identify the optimal balance between coverage and profitability. Third, we will use early institutional partnerships with county governments and development partners as anchor customers. These partners provide predictable upfront payments and subscription revenue, allowing us to validate recurring revenue assumptions and cash-flow timing while de-risking capital investments in device manufacturing. Fourth, we will implement real-time financial dashboards that track revenue, costs, and contribution margins per device, per agent, and per geography. This enables rapid iteration of pricing, agent incentives, and operational processes based on performance data. Finally, we will validate farmer retention and repeat usage, ensuring that farmers return for multiple soil tests across seasons. Only after achieving consistent positive margins, strong agent productivity, and repeat demand across pilot regions will we scale manufacturing, agent onboarding, and geographic expansion.

label.plain: If available, please share any financial projections you have developed to support your earned revenue strategy.

field.label: If available, please share any financial projections you have developed to support your earned revenue strategy.
field.value: In the next 12 months, we project total revenues of approximately $990,000. This includes $750,000 from soil testing services, driven by serving 50,000 farmers at an average price of $15 per test, and $240,000 from institutional partnerships, based on onboarding five county governments procuring a total of 100 devices under our down-payment and monthly subscription model. Variable costs include agent commissions (40% of service revenue), SMS and cloud processing, logistics, and device maintenance, while fixed costs include core staff salaries, technology infrastructure, and office operations. Under this base case, the stream reaches operational breakeven by Month 12. Over a 3-year horizon, projections assume gradual scaling to 300+ devices, 150–200 active agents, and service delivery to over 200,000 farmers annually across Kenya and neighboring countries. As utilization per device increases, unit costs decline, improving gross margins. Institutional subscriptions provide predictable recurring revenue, helping stabilize cash flows and finance continued expansion without reliance on grant funding. Our projections are supported by conservative assumptions on agent productivity, farmer uptake, and device utilization, informed by current field performance with 50 active agents each serving 1,000 farmers annually.

label.plain: If successful, how would this earned revenue stream help advance your organization’s mission and growth? How does it contribute to your long-term sustainability and impact goals?

field.label: If successful, how would this earned revenue stream help advance your organization’s mission and growth? How does it contribute to your long-term sustainability and impact goals?
field.value: Earned revenue stream will be a critical driver of UjuziKilimo's mission, growth, and long-term sustainability. By generating predictable income directly from farmers and institutional partners, the model enables us to continuously deliver affordable, data-driven soil intelligence to smallholder farmers without relying solely on grants or donor funding. This ensures that evidence-based farming decisions become a permanent, scalable service rather than a time-bound project. Revenue from soil testing services allows us to reinvest in expanding device deployment, training more youth and women as field agents, and reaching additional farming communities. Each new device and agent increases our ability to serve thousands of farmers, directly advancing our mission to replace guesswork with actionable agricultural data. The agent-led model also creates local employment and entrepreneurship opportunities, reinforcing inclusive growth and gender equity objectives. Institutional sales and subscriptions to county governments and development partners provide stable, recurring revenue that strengthens cash flow and reduces financial risk. This predictable income supports ongoing investment in technology improvements, data analytics, and climate-resilient agronomic models, enabling us to improve the quality and relevance of recommendations over time. In the long term, a financially sustainable revenue stream positions UjuziKilimo to scale across Kenya and into other African markets, reaching millions of farmers. As scale increases, the cost per farmer declines while impact multiplies higher yields, increased incomes, improved food security, and greater resilience to climate shocks. Ultimately, earned revenue ensures that UjuziKilimo can grow impact at scale while remaining mission-driven, locally rooted, and financially resilient.

label.plain: How do you intend to use Follow-on Funding to support the development of financial sustainability within your organization?

field.label: How do you intend to use Follow-on Funding to support the development of financial sustainability within your organization?
field.value: We intend to use the $50,000 Follow-on Funding as catalytic capital to accelerate UjuziKilimo's transition to a financially sustainable, earned-revenue model. The funding will be deployed toward high-leverage, upfront investments that directly increase revenue-generating capacity and reduce operational risk. Approximately $32,000 will be allocated to the manufacturing of 40 soil testing devices at $800 per device. These devices will be deployed through trained field agents and institutional partners, immediately expanding our ability to deliver paid soil testing services and onboard county governments and development partners under subscription agreements. Around $10,000 will be used to onboard and train 50 new field agents at $200 per agent. This investment strengthens last-mile service delivery, improves agent productivity, and enables us to rapidly scale farmer outreach while creating income-generating opportunities for youth and women. The remaining $8,000 will support technology and operational systems, including cloud infrastructure, SMS delivery, data analytics enhancements, and financial tracking tools. These improvements reduce per-test costs, improve service quality, and enable real-time monitoring of unit economics to guide scaling decisions. By funding device production, agent expansion, and core systems, the $50,000 Follow-on Funding will unlock significant earned revenue growth, shorten the path to breakeven, and position Ujuzikilimo to sustainably scale its impact, reaching more farmers, increasing productivity, and strengthening food security without long-term dependence on grant funding.

label.plain: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:

field.label: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:
field.value:
NEIGHBORHOOD BENCHES (NB) educate young people on leadership and good practices that break cycles of youth violence and incarceration. In underrepresented neighborhoods, with the help of directly impacted people, NB is teaching young people to act as leaders for finding solutions and implementing them.
Central to our mission is to pair experienced mentors with youth in casual yet meaningful settings. Creating this nurturing environment promotes the personal and professional growth of young individuals, allowing them to express themselves, confront challenges, and envision brighter futures

label.plain: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.

field.label: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.
field.value:
The Neighborhood Benches 40-week program is a bold and strategic initiative designed to empower young people while simultaneously nurturing the growth of adult mentors within the community. It begins with a comprehensive assessment of local needs and challenges, laying the groundwork for a thoughtful rollout that connects system-impacted youth with credible adult messengers. Each week, participants delve into critical themes such as community awareness, leadership identity, and project-based learning, enhancing their ability to take ownership in fostering positive change within their neighborhoods. Through engaging discussions, workshops, and hands-on projects, they are inspired to reflect on their experiences and make meaningful contributions.
Programs & Services: Neighborhood Leadership 2.0 Neighborhood-School Teaching Practicum (NSTP) Design Your Future: (DFY) Bench Talk PhD Storytelling Project Mentorship Program with Credible Messenger Mentors Community Activation & Transformative Fellowship Food Distribution Program

label.plain: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

field.label: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

label.plain: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

field.label: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.
field.value:
Since its launch in 2017, the Neighborhood Benches initiative has significantly transformed communities across NYC and beyond, uplifting countless individuals. This program showcases the inspiring journeys of adults who have taken on leadership roles in various organizations and the lives of hundreds of young people.
Visionary leaders like James Young, III of AHHIM, Shams DeBaron, Monique Ferguson-Riley of the Youth Justice Center, and others exemplify the initiative’s success. With Neighborhood Benches' coaching and support, these leaders have created impactful organizations that address community needs.
At its core, the Neighborhood Benches blueprint fosters mentorship and wellness, empowering individuals from similar backgrounds to reshape narratives and practices. This grassroots approach not only inspires young people but also nurtures a sense of belonging within the community. By engaging mentors authentically, Neighborhood Benches transforms lives and strengthens community bonds.
Additionally, the initiative supports over 1,000 families through programs and food distribution, directly impacting more than 500 young people and 80 adults each year. By compensating local adults to become mentors and working with five young people each during the summer as practice, the program creates a safe space for discussing challenges and goals, reinforcing the community's strength and resilience.

label.plain: How do you plan to increase the financial sustainability of your work through earned revenue? What product or service do you plan to sell, to whom, and how will you operationalize this work within your organization?

field.label: How do you plan to increase the financial sustainability of your work through earned revenue? What product or service do you plan to sell, to whom, and how will you operationalize this work within your organization?
field.value:
Neighborhood Benches, Inc. is thrilled to announce the launch of the Bench Talk Retreat Clubs, a groundbreaking initiative aimed at expanding our services and enhancing community wellness. Our first location will be in the South Bronx, specifically at the Andrew Jackson Houses, where we will create a therapeutic retreat designed to empower community members to prioritize their mental and emotional well-being. This space will serve as a model for healing and connection, specifically tailored for Black and Brown individuals, demonstrating how a supportive environment can inspire individuals to invest in themselves and their community.
Each room within the Retreat Clubs will feature its own dedicated green space, meticulously designed to foster therapeutic and wellness experiences. These individual green spaces are intended to provide a calming atmosphere that promotes relaxation and rejuvenation.
Service Pricing Structure Individual Session: $50 per hour Group Session (max 5 participants): $150 per hour Membership Program: $250 per month (includes 5 free sessions)
Expected Revenue 30 Individual Sessions (2 hours each): $3,000 15 Group Sessions (1 hour each): $2,250 10 Memberships: $2,500 Total Revenue: $7,750 Community Events (5 events, 5 hours): $1,200 Total Earned Revenue: $13,750 Annual Revenue Projection: $165,000 (+ $35,400)
In collaboration with therapeutic professionals and mentors, we will provide crucial mental wellness support tailored to the needs of our community. Each retreat will also feature unique QR codes for easy access to mental health specialists, ensuring that help is just a scan away.

label.plain: Tell us more about your target market, who are they, how big is the market and what problem does your offering solve for them

field.label: Tell us more about your target market, who are they, how big is the market and what problem does your offering solve for them
field.value:
With nearly 1.75 million children under 18 in NYC, understanding the mental health of Black and Brown youth is crucial. Current engagement strategies are insufficient, leaving gaps that may lead to coping through violence, drugs, or isolation.A 2023 survey revealed concerning trends: 22% of Black and Brown teens reported severe depressive symptoms. In terms of general worries, 44% sometimes worried, while 20% always did. Looking ahead, 34% reported sometimes worrying about the future, and 24% always did. Furthermore, 42% sometimes worried about something bad happening to them, and 41% worried about their families.
Our approach stands out for 3 key reasons. We created a soft support system through our Bench Talk Initiatives, which includes a card game, benches, and QR codes.
We’ve tested the Bench Talk initiative for 3 years and received positive feedback from the community, particularly young people and parents. Bench Talk strengthens family relationship and mentorship. We understand the challenges young people and parents face when seeking support to navigate difficulties, unpack traumatic experiences, and connect with mentorship and mental health services.
In NYC, daily life offers vibrant experiences that shape neighborhoods, especially for Black and Brown children. However, societal pressures persist, dictating emotional restraint with phrases like "boys don’t cry" and "therapy isn’t for colored boys and girls", all while our young people are challenged with school, challenged with understanding family struggles, choices, health and navigating their own neighborhood.

field.value: Over the past 7 years, we have been successful with raising funds for new projects, while continuing our mentorship services. Based on the section above, we plan to bring in total of $35,400.00 after all expenses are paid. These earnings will provide us with funding support for the following year and assist with purchasing of equipment and maintain existing equipment.

label.plain: How will you test and validate the financial viability of this stream before scaling?

field.label: How will you test and validate the financial viability of this stream before scaling?
field.value:
#1 and #2 will be the most important as it relates to start-up, but we will consider all listed below: 1. Market Research Upon our opening, we will implement surveys and focus groups within the community to better understand their needs and their willingness to invest in therapeutic services. Our established relationships with these communities, built through mentorship and employment initiatives since 2017, will enable us to effectively engage and meet their unique wellness needs.
2. Cost Analysis For our initial location in the South Bronx, we are committed to maintaining rental costs at $5,000. This range reflects both our established relationships within the community and the realities of the local real estate market.
Startup Costs: Lease or purchase of storefronts Renovation and design costs for therapeutic rooms Equipment and supplies for services (e.g., massage tables and chairs) Marketing and branding expenses
Operational Costs: Salaries for mentors, clerk and mental health professionals Utility bills and maintenance costs Insurance and licensing fees
We will also look at community feedback so that we have a better understanding of how it is impacting them and for recommendations focus don other areas the services will have an impact on.

field.label: If available, please share any financial projections you have developed to support your earned revenue strategy.
field.value:
We raised $400,000 this year for our Bench Talk Initiative, which is designed to pay for mental health first aid and psychological first aid training, as well as compensate our mentors. In this plan, we will secure a new site to pilot the Bench Talk Retreat Club. The below numbers are our project earned revenue for the 2027 year: Revenue Streams
Service Pricing Structure: Individual Session: $50 per hour Group Session (max 5 participants): $150 per hour Membership Program: $250 per month (includes 5 free sessions)
Expected Revenue: 20 Individual Sessions (1 hour each): $1,000 5 Group Sessions (1 hour each): $750 5 Memberships: $1,000
Community Events: 5 hrs $1,200
Funding Goals Corporate Sponsorships: Aim for $2,000 per month in sponsorships. Crowdfunding Campaign: Set a goal of $5,000 Private Foundation: $150,000

label.plain: If successful, how would this earned revenue stream help advance your organization’s mission and growth? How does it contribute to your long-term sustainability and impact goals?

field.label: If successful, how would this earned revenue stream help advance your organization’s mission and growth? How does it contribute to your long-term sustainability and impact goals?
field.value:
Our work is to reduce youth violence and incarceration. Initiatives like Bench Talk harness these profound benefits to enhance community mental health. With over 100 mental health initiatives currently operational in New York City, the incorporation of models like Bench Talk can significantly fortify the overall support network for mental wellness. This model stands as a timely and necessary intervention, promoting community connection and mental health support within urban environments.
The integration of natural environments and nature-based activities into mental health treatment is gaining significant international recognition. These therapeutic spaces offer essential benefits, countering the detrimental effects of our technology-driven, climate-controlled, and often high-stress lives. A growing body of scientific literature underscores that engaging with nature can foster improved health and well-being across various dimensions—physiological, emotional, cognitive, social, and spiritual.
The Bench Talk Retreat Clubs are pivotal in increasing access to community-based mental health initiatives. Our community-centric approach not only addresses immediate mental health needs but also cultivates resilience through mentorship and resource accessibility. By prioritizing peaceful, therapeutic environments empowering neighbors to heal, connect, and thrive.
The replicable nature of the Bench Talk Retreat Club model is vital for establishing a network of clubs that can reach underserved communities. Each new club represents a step towards equitable access to wellness resources, creating a ripple effect that enhances the quality of life for all residents. By expanding this initiative, we can ensure that more individuals benefit from the restorative power of nature, leading to healthier and more connected communities.

label.plain: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:

field.label: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:
field.value:
We envision a future where linguistic diversity is not a barrier to opportunity, but a bridge to collective human knowledge, where local languages are as digitally alive as global ones, powered by the most advanced technology humanity has to offer.
Our Mission is to accelerate the preservation and revitalization of indigenous languages by deploying Artificial Intelligence as a force multiplier. We transform centuries of oral and written heritage into high-performance digital assets, ensuring that underrepresented communities have the tools to communicate, learn, and lead in their own languages.

label.plain: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.

field.label: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.
field.value:
At the Foundation for the Promotion of Local Languages (FPLL), we are pioneering a future where technology honors heritage rather than erasing it. At our core, we utilize Artificial Intelligence as an accelerator to bridge the digital divide for underrepresented communities. Our primary activity centers on "Collective Intelligence" campaigns, where we collaborate with native speakers to document and digitize linguistic data. Unlike traditional extractive models, we treat this data as shared intellectual wealth and provide direct funding to local communities by paying contributors double the local minimum wage. This ensures that language preservation is a driver of economic dignity.
To move from preservation to participation, we distribute open-source AI tools and specialized hardware. By providing localized Speech Language Models and translation APIs, we enable developers and educators to build digital solutions that speak the language of the people. Our hardware initiatives, including solar-powered edge devices, ensure that even the most remote communities have the infrastructure to engage with the digital world. These resources empower individuals to learn, create, and connect globally on their own terms. Ultimately, our work facilitates a paradigm shift where indigenous voices are no longer sidelined by a dominant language barrier. Through real-time AI translation and localized leadership hubs, we ensure that every speaker, regardless of their tongue, has the power to converse and lead in the global discourse. We believe that when a community can lead in its native language, it doesn't just survive; it thrives as a vital contributor to the world's collective future.

label.plain: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

field.label: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

label.plain: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

field.label: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.
field.value:
Since completing our initial fellowship, we have evolved into a sustainable hybrid organization, bridging the gap between social impact and commercial viability. Our growth has been solidified through prestigious accelerators including Google, Nvidia Inception, Cascador, and Black Ambition, which helped refine a business model that generated nearly $300,000 in revenue last year, with a roadmap to reach $1 million next year. We have transitioned from a promising concept to a technical leader, releasing proprietary language models in 10 African languages, more than any other company on the continent.
This technical infrastructure now serves close to one million people, both through our direct products and third-party platforms leveraging our technology. FPLL drives this expansion through a "Collective Intelligence" model, providing dignified gig work to over 14,000 volunteers who contribute to our datasets. By ensuring these contributors are paid at least double the local minimum wage, we turn linguistic preservation into a powerful economic engine. Through several award-winning initiatives, we provide open-source AI tools and hardware that empower communities and African businesses to learn, create, and lead globally. We are proving that linguistic inclusivity is not just a moral goal, but a scalable, sustainable frontier for global innovation.

label.plain: How do you plan to increase the financial sustainability of your work through earned revenue? What product or service do you plan to sell, to whom, and how will you operationalize this work within your organization?

field.label: How do you plan to increase the financial sustainability of your work through earned revenue? What product or service do you plan to sell, to whom, and how will you operationalize this work within your organization?
field.value:
To achieve long-term financial sustainability and reach our revenue targets, we are scaling a hybrid model that converts our linguistic "Collective Intelligence" into high-demand B2B product extensions. Our primary revenue stream comes from selling specialized AI integration tools and API access to our ten proprietary African language models, the most comprehensive suite on the continent. We target two main segments: African enterprises requiring localized customer engagement tools and global corporations seeking to enter the African market with authentic, culturally nuanced digital interfaces. By offering these businesses tailored LLM fine-tuning and localization services, we solve the "language gap" that previously hindered digital expansion in the region.
Operationally, this revenue-driven side of the organization subsidizes our open-source initiatives and community hardware distribution, reducing our reliance on traditional grants. This structure allows us to reinvest profits into R&D and community expansion, ensuring that our growth is powered by the market value we create.

label.plain: Tell us more about your target market, who are they, how big is the market and what problem does your offering solve for them

field.label: Tell us more about your target market, who are they, how big is the market and what problem does your offering solve for them
field.value:
We target the massive digital exclusion gap within Africa, where over 500 million consumers speaking 2,000+ local languages are currently underserved. Our primary market consists of enterprise customer experience leads in high-growth sectors: banks, telcos serving over 150 million mobile users, and digital health platforms like Helium Health. The economic opportunity is vast, with Africa’s digital health sector projected to reach $16.6 billion by 2030 and the Middle East and Africa voice recognition market exceeding $790 million by 2026.
The critical problem we solve is the "language friction" that stifles business growth. Currently, customers face grueling 15-minute wait times and inefficient 8-minute calls because human agents cannot scale across diverse dialects. This leads to over 30% customer churn and millions in lost revenue, reflected in stagnant banking CSAT scores. Indigenius bridges this gap with instant, multilingual voice AI agents and a Creator Studio for automated dubbing and avatars. By integrating our proprietary ASR, TTS, and LLM stacks, enterprises can slash costs tenfold while providing 24/7 service in native tongues. Our impact is already scaling through major partnerships, such as our 10-million-user transcription pilot with Huawei. We are transforming customer care from a cost center into a powerful competitive advantage, unlocking inclusive growth for Africa’s underserved markets.

label.plain: What are the main variable costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., materials, labor costs, delivery, etc.)?

field.label: What are the main variable costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., materials, labor costs, delivery, etc.)?
field.value:
Operating the Indigenius revenue stream involves several key variable costs that scale directly with our volume of service and the depth of our linguistic reach. As we transition toward our $1 million revenue target in 2025, the most significant driver of cost is computational infrastructure. Powering real-time, multilingual voice AI requires high-performance GPU clusters for inference. These cloud compute costs are metered by the second; every minute of a multilingual call processed for a bank or telco incurs direct expenses for Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR), Large Language Model (LLM) processing, and Text-to-Speech (TTS) synthesis. As our user base grows toward the one million mark, these technical "tokens" and API throughput fees represent our primary cost of goods sold.
Beyond the digital infrastructure, our data procurement and labor costs remain a vital variable expense. Our unique "Collective Intelligence" model relies on a network of over 14,000 volunteers. Because we are committed to paying double the local minimum wage for this specialized gig work, our costs increase as we expand into new languages or deepen the datasets for existing ones. Unlike static software, AI models require ongoing "retraining" and reinforcement from human feedback to maintain accuracy and cultural relevance. Consequently, every new language model we release or update involves a direct surge in payouts to our community contributors.
Finally, we anticipate variable costs related to telephony and hardware delivery. For our enterprise clients, bridging AI to traditional phone lines involves per-minute SIP trunking and PSTN connectivity fees. For our "last mile" community initiatives, the variable costs include the manufacturing and distribution of solar-powered edge devices

label.plain: What are the main fixed costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., equipment, pro-rata salaries, rent etc.)?

field.label: What are the main fixed costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., equipment, pro-rata salaries, rent etc.)?
field.value:
The most significant fixed cost is our Technical Infrastructure. Since we host proprietary LLMs in 10 African languages, we maintain substantial cloud and on-premise compute power. This includes recurring monthly expenses for high-performance GPU instances (such as NVIDIA A100s or H100s) necessary for real-time inference and model serving. These costs are complemented by the pro-rata investment in Proprietary Hardware, particularly our specialized Edge AI devices and localized server hubs, which require ongoing maintenance and occasional technology refreshes to handle increasing traffic from enterprises like Huawei and major fintechs.
Equally vital are Expert Salaries. We allocate pro-rata compensation for a lean team of high-level AI specialists, MLOps engineers, and product managers who maintain our "Creator Studio" and API stability. While our data collection is powered by a massive volunteer network, the fixed management of this "Collective Intelligence" pipeline requires dedicated community leads to oversee the ethical distribution of funds and quality control. Finally, we maintain Operational and Compliance Costs, including rent for our physical hubs and the necessary legal and security certifications required to partner with highly regulated sectors like banking, telecommunications, and healthcare. This structured allocation of fixed costs ensures that as we scale, our infrastructure remains robust, secure, and uniquely capable of serving the African enterprise market.

label.plain: How do you plan to price your product or service? What factors informed your pricing strategy?

field.label: How do you plan to price your product or service? What factors informed your pricing strategy?
field.value:
Our pricing strategy is designed to balance enterprise-grade scalability with our core mission of accessibility, shifting away from a "one-size-fits-all" model to a tiered, usage-based structure. We primarily employ a SaaS-based API subscription model combined with volume-based consumption charges. For fintechs and telcos, this involves a monthly platform fee for access to our proprietary "Creator Studio" and voice AI agents, supplemented by a "per-minute" or "per-character" fee for Automated Speech Recognition (ASR) and Text-to-Speech (TTS) processing.
Several critical factors informed this strategy. First, we conducted a Competitive Value Analysis against global giants; while Western AI providers might offer lower generic rates, they lack the accuracy for local dialects, leading to the high churn we aim to solve. By pricing our services at a premium for quality but at a 10x cost reduction compared to human-led call centers, we provide a clear ROI for CX leads. Second, our Cost-plus-Impact Foundation was vital; our pricing must cover the high fixed costs of GPU compute and the ethical mandate of paying our 14,000+ data contributors double the local minimum wage.
Finally, we factored in Market Elasticity within the African enterprise landscape. We offer "Lite" tiers for emerging digital health startups to encourage ecosystem growth, while charging enterprise-level fees for banks and telcos that require high-availability SLAs and custom LLM fine-tuning. This hybrid approach ensures financial sustainability, allowing us to hit our $1 million revenue target while subsidizing the open-source tools that empower the broader community.

label.plain: What upfront investments are needed to deliver this product or service (e.g., staff, technology, infrastructure, etc.)?

field.label: What upfront investments are needed to deliver this product or service (e.g., staff, technology, infrastructure, etc.)?
field.value: We require a robust upfront investment in high-performance technology, specialized talent, and ethical data acquisition. This capital expenditure is designed to move beyond traditional API-wrapping and instead solidify our position as the primary owners of African linguistic AI infrastructure.

label.plain: What is your projected revenue from this stream within the next 12 months?

field.label: What is your projected revenue from this stream within the next 12 months?

label.plain: When do you expect to reach breakeven for this stream (i.e., when revenue covers all associated costs)?

field.label: When do you expect to reach breakeven for this stream (i.e., when revenue covers all associated costs)?

label.plain: How will you test and validate the financial viability of this stream before scaling?

field.label: How will you test and validate the financial viability of this stream before scaling?
field.value: To ensure the Indigenius AI revenue stream is both profitable and sustainable, we are implementing a rigorous validation framework focused on three critical levers: unit economics, technical scalability, and enterprise retention. Before a full-scale rollout, we are executing a series of "Phased Pilots" to stress-test our assumptions in real-world environments. The cornerstone of our validation is the Margin-to-Impact Ratio. We are currently tracking the "cost per inference" against the "revenue per interaction" for our 10 proprietary language models. Financial viability depends on the "stickiness" of the product, which is directly tied to technical reliability. We validate this through Performance-to-Churn Correlation. Finally, we are validating our operational efficiency. We are auditing the "time-to-market" for new language models to ensure our Collective Intelligence pipeline can scale without a linear increase in management costs.

label.plain: If available, please share any financial projections you have developed to support your earned revenue strategy.

field.label: If available, please share any financial projections you have developed to support your earned revenue strategy.
field.value:
Couldn't attach but here it a prose below.
Our path to $1M in 2026 is anchored by three high-margin pillars. Enterprise Voice AI & ASR ($600,000): This is our primary growth engine. By converting current pilots with banks and telcos into full-scale production contracts, we anticipate serving millions of daily interactions. With the Middle East and Africa voice recognition market hitting $790M+ this year, capturing just a fraction of the customer service volume for major fintechs like Flutterwave allows us to reach this target through recurring API usage fees.
Creator Studio & Content Localization ($300,000): We are capitalizing on the demand for localized digital health and educational content. By selling subscription-based access to our TTS, dubbing, and avatar tools to platforms like Helium Health, we enable them to localize their outreach across multiple languages instantly, creating a steady stream of "Platform-as-a-Service" revenue.
Strategic Hardware & Custom LLM Fine-tuning ($100,000): High-security sectors, such as banking and government, require on-premise or specialized hardware solutions. This revenue comes from one-time setup fees and specialized maintenance for localized Edge AI units.

label.plain: If successful, how would this earned revenue stream help advance your organization’s mission and growth? How does it contribute to your long-term sustainability and impact goals?

field.label: If successful, how would this earned revenue stream help advance your organization’s mission and growth? How does it contribute to your long-term sustainability and impact goals?
field.value:
Success in 2026 will transform us from a high-potential startup into a permanent, self-sustaining infrastructure for linguistic justice. By decoupling our core operations from the unpredictability of traditional grant cycles, this earned revenue stream creates a "Sustainability Flywheel." Every dollar earned from an enterprise API call or a Creator Studio subscription directly subsidizes the expansion of our Collective Intelligence network. This allows us to scale our impact beyond the initial 10 languages, reinvesting profits to pay thousands more indigenous contributors double the local minimum wage to digitize underrepresented dialects that the commercial market might otherwise ignore.
This financial independence is the bedrock of our long-term growth. It enables us to move from "preservation" to "leadership," providing the capital needed to maintain a world-class R&D team that keeps our proprietary models at the cutting edge of AI. As we scale, the revenue allows us to distribute open-source tools and solar-powered hardware to remote communities at zero cost, ensuring that the most marginalized voices have the same "accelerator" technology as global banks.

label.plain: How do you intend to use Follow-on Funding to support the development of financial sustainability within your organization?

field.label: How do you intend to use Follow-on Funding to support the development of financial sustainability within your organization?
field.value:
A follow-on investment will serve as a targeted bridge to our revenue goal in 2026 by focusing on two high-leverage areas: aggressive customer acquisition and the expansion of our "Collective Intelligence" pipeline from 14,000 to 18,000 volunteers. This funding will allow us to move from successful pilots to a dominant market position by strengthening both our sales engine and our proprietary data moat.
To accelerate Customer Acquisition, we will deploy capital into a specialized enterprise sales and "Go-To-Market" (GTM) strategy. This involves hiring technical account managers capable of navigating the complex integration requirements of Nigeria’s businesses.
Simultaneously, we will allocate funds to scale our Data Collection Infrastructure, expanding our volunteer network by 4,000 new contributors. This growth is not just about volume; it is about deepening the accuracy of our 10 proprietary language models. By paying these 18,000 volunteers double the local minimum wage, we stimulate local economies while securing a massive, ethically sourced dataset that global competitors cannot replicate.

label.plain: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:

field.label: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:
field.value: Solar Freeze’s mission is to reduce food loss, increase incomes, and strengthen climate resilience for smallholder farmers and micro-entrepreneurs through affordable, solar-powered cold storage. Our vision is a future where no farmer or food vendor loses their livelihood because of heat, lack of energy, or poor infrastructure, and where clean, community-owned cold chains enable thriving, resilient local food systems across Africa.

label.plain: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.

field.label: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.
field.value:
Solar Freeze delivers solar-powered cold storage solutions that enable smallholder farmers, food vendors, fishers, and agri-microenterprises to safely store perishable goods and reduce post-harvest losses. We design, install, and operate off-grid cold rooms powered by solar energy and smart battery systems, making them suitable for rural, peri-urban, and refugee-hosting communities with unreliable or no electricity.
We provide access to these cold storage units through a Pay-As-You-Go (PAYGO) model that allows users to pay small, affordable daily or per-crate fees via mobile money, removing the barrier of high upfront costs. Our systems are monitored using IoT sensors that track temperature, energy use, and uptime, ensuring reliability and enabling remote diagnostics.
Solar Freeze also operates a micro-franchising program that trains and supports women and youth to own and manage cold storage hubs as small businesses. These local operators earn income while providing essential services to farmers and vendors in their communities. We offer training in business management, equipment operation, customer engagement, and basic maintenance.
In addition, we work with cooperatives, health facilities, and humanitarian organizations to provide cold storage for vaccines, dairy, and fresh food, improving food security and public health. Through data and AI-enabled tools, we continuously improve performance, pricing, and service delivery, helping our partners and users build more resilient, climate-smart food systems.

label.plain: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

field.label: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

label.plain: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

field.label: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.
field.value:
Since completing the Echoing Green Fellowship, Solar Freeze has grown from a promising pilot into a scaled, operating climate-resilience enterprise serving hundreds of thousands of people. We have expanded deployment of solar-powered cold storage units across multiple counties in Kenya, including rural farming regions and refugee-hosting communities, significantly increasing our geographic and community reach. Today, our systems support more than 300,000 smallholder farmers, food vendors, and micro-entrepreneurs who rely on reliable cold storage to protect their livelihoods.
Our impact has deepened as well. We have reduced post-harvest losses by up to 30–70% in many of the communities we serve, helping users increase incomes, stabilize prices, and reduce food waste. We have also strengthened our PAYGO financing model, making cold storage affordable and accessible without requiring upfront capital, while maintaining strong repayment rates and operational sustainability.
Programmatically, we launched and expanded our women- and youth-led micro-franchise network, training local operators to own and manage cold storage hubs as viable businesses. We also integrated IoT monitoring and early-stage AI analytics into our systems to improve reliability, asset tracking, and performance management.
In parallel, Solar Freeze has built stronger partnerships with cooperatives, NGOs, development agencies, and technology partners, positioning the organization for regional scale and long-term sustainability.
