label.plain: How do you plan to increase the financial sustainability of your work through earned revenue? What product or service do you plan to sell, to whom, and how will you operationalize this work within your organization?

field.label: How do you plan to increase the financial sustainability of your work through earned revenue? What product or service do you plan to sell, to whom, and how will you operationalize this work within your organization?
field.value:
Solar Freeze’s earned revenue model is built around delivering solar-powered cold storage as an essential service to smallholder farmers, food vendors, fishers, and micro-enterprises that depend on refrigeration to protect their inventory and income. We provide access to our cold storage hubs through a Pay-As-You-Go (PAYGO) model that allows users to pay small, affordable fees per crate or per day via mobile money. This converts cold storage from a high-cost asset into a reliable, ongoing service that aligns with users’ cash flows.
To increase financial sustainability, we will continue expanding this PAYGO service into new high-demand markets, including rural aggregation points, urban fresh markets, and refugee-hosting areas. As utilization grows, each unit becomes more profitable, generating predictable recurring revenue that supports operations, maintenance, and future deployments.
We also generate revenue through our micro-franchise model. Women and youth operators manage cold storage hubs as local businesses, collecting user fees and sharing revenue with Solar Freeze. This ensures high utilization, local ownership, and long-term asset care while providing Solar Freeze with a scalable income stream.
In addition, we sell institutional cold storage services to cooperatives, health facilities, and humanitarian organizations for vaccine, dairy, and food storage, creating higher-margin contracts that cross-subsidize community access.
Operationally, we support this through a centralized PAYGO platform, field service teams, and data-driven asset management that keeps costs low and uptime high, enabling Solar Freeze to grow sustainably through earned revenue rather than reliance on grants alone.

label.plain: Tell us more about your target market, who are they, how big is the market and what problem does your offering solve for them

field.label: Tell us more about your target market, who are they, how big is the market and what problem does your offering solve for them
field.value:
Solar Freeze’s primary target market is smallholder farmers, food vendors, fishers, and agri-microenterprises operating in low-income, off-grid, and climate-vulnerable communities across Kenya and East Africa. These users rely on selling fresh produce, fish, dairy, and meat for their livelihoods but lack access to reliable refrigeration. As a result, they lose 30–50% of their products to spoilage, forcing them to sell quickly at low prices or discard unsold food.
This market is large and underserved. In Kenya alone, there are over 7 million smallholder farmers and hundreds of thousands of informal food traders and fishers. Across East Africa, tens of millions of people depend on perishable food value chains, yet less than 10% have access to any form of cold storage. Post-harvest losses in the region amount to billions of dollars annually and are a major driver of food insecurity and poverty.
Solar Freeze solves this by providing affordable, solar-powered cold storage as a service. Our PAYGO model allows users to pay small, flexible fees instead of purchasing expensive equipment or relying on diesel-powered refrigeration. This enables them to store products for longer, sell when prices are higher, and reduce waste. For our customers, this means higher incomes, more stable cash flow, and greater resilience to heat, climate shocks, and market volatility.

label.plain: What are the main variable costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., materials, labor costs, delivery, etc.)?

field.label: What are the main variable costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., materials, labor costs, delivery, etc.)?
field.value:
Solar Freeze’s earned revenue model is built around operating and financing solar-powered cold storage units that are used by farmers and food microenterprises on a PAYGO basis. The main variable costs to operate this revenue stream fall into five categories.
First are energy and equipment-related costs. While the systems are solar-powered, we incur ongoing costs for battery degradation, inverter replacement, refrigeration components, and routine servicing to keep units operating reliably in hot, dusty, and remote environments.
Second are local operations and labor costs. Each unit is managed by a trained micro-franchisee who earns a share of revenue, along with field technicians who handle installation, preventive maintenance, and repairs. We also incur costs for customer onboarding, training, and ongoing support.
Third are logistics and deployment costs, including transport of cold rooms, solar panels, and spare parts to rural sites, as well as relocation or redeployment when units move between markets.
Fourth are platform and transaction costs, including mobile money fees, PAYGO software licensing, cloud hosting, data connectivity, and IoT monitoring that tracks usage, temperature, and repayment.
Finally, there are credit and financing costs, including losses from defaults, repossession or redeployment of underperforming units, and the cost of capital used to finance equipment. Together, these variable costs scale with the number of units deployed and directly influence pricing and profitability.

label.plain: What are the main fixed costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., equipment, pro-rata salaries, rent etc.)?

field.label: What are the main fixed costs you anticipate to operate this revenue stream (e.g., equipment, pro-rata salaries, rent etc.)?
field.value:
Solar Freeze’s fixed cost base reflects the infrastructure and team required to run a distributed, PAYGO-enabled cold storage network at scale.
The largest fixed cost is core staff and management. This includes engineering and product development (hardware, IoT, and software), finance and credit management, operations leadership, and partnerships and sales. These roles do not scale linearly with each additional unit deployed but are required to design, manage, and improve the system as a whole.
Second is technology and platform infrastructure. We maintain a central PAYGO platform, cloud servers, data storage, cybersecurity, and analytics tools that support all deployed units. These costs remain largely fixed across wide ranges of deployment volume.
Third is facilities and logistics hubs. Solar Freeze operates warehousing, assembly, and service centers where cold storage units, solar components, and spare parts are stored, assembled, and refurbished. We also incur rent, utilities, and insurance for these facilities.
Fourth are corporate and compliance costs, including accounting, audits, legal, regulatory compliance, and corporate governance across our operating entities.
Finally, there are brand, partnerships, and business development costs, including communications, market development, and strategic partnerships with governments, NGOs, and buyers. These investments are essential to securing long-term contracts and expanding into new regions but do not depend on the number of farmers using a unit in a given month.

label.plain: How do you plan to price your product or service? What factors informed your pricing strategy?

field.label: How do you plan to price your product or service? What factors informed your pricing strategy?
field.value:
Solar Freeze prices its solar-powered cold storage and digital services using a Pay-As-You-Go (PAYGO) and usage-based model designed to be affordable for smallholder farmers while remaining commercially sustainable.
Farmers and produce aggregators pay a small daily or per-crate fee to store their crops, rather than purchasing equipment upfront. Typical pricing is calibrated to be lower than the value of the food that would otherwise be lost, so users see an immediate return. For example, if a farmer avoids losing KES 1,000 of tomatoes, paying KES 100–200 for cold storage is economically rational and attractive. This ensures strong demand and high willingness to pay.
Micro-franchise operators (mostly women and youth) earn revenue from these payments and share a portion with Solar Freeze to cover asset financing, maintenance, and platform costs. Larger users such as dairy cooperatives, traders, and humanitarian agencies pay higher, contract-based rates for dedicated capacity, data services, and reliability guarantees, cross-subsidizing small farmers.
Our pricing strategy is informed by four key factors: 1. Ability to pay in rural and refugee-hosting communities; 2. Value created through reduced spoilage and higher market prices; 3. Unit economics including equipment cost, energy, and servicing; and 4. Benchmarking against alternatives such as ice, diesel refrigeration, or produce loss.
By combining PAYGO with tiered enterprise pricing, Solar Freeze ensures both inclusivity and long-term financial sustainability.

label.plain: What upfront investments are needed to deliver this product or service (e.g., staff, technology, infrastructure, etc.)?

field.label: What upfront investments are needed to deliver this product or service (e.g., staff, technology, infrastructure, etc.)?
field.value:
To deliver Solar Freeze’s solar-powered cold storage service at scale, several upfront investments are required across infrastructure, technology, and human capital.
The largest upfront cost is cold storage and energy infrastructure, including solar-powered refrigeration units, battery systems, and modular cold rooms deployed at aggregation points, markets, and farming hubs. These assets are capital intensive but long-lived, typically operating for 8–10 years, making them well-suited for PAYGO and asset-finance models.
Second, we invest in digital and IoT technology, including temperature sensors, energy meters, connectivity modules, and our PAYGO and monitoring platform. These systems enable real-time tracking of usage, asset performance, and repayments, which is essential for credit risk management, maintenance, and investor reporting.
Third, there are software and AI development costs to support demand forecasting, spoilage prediction, dynamic pricing, and credit scoring for micro-franchisees and users. This technology allows Solar Freeze to scale efficiently while keeping default rates low.
Fourth, we invest in people and operations, including field technicians, franchise trainers, customer support, sales staff, and operations managers who deploy, maintain, and grow the network. Initial training of women and youth micro-franchisees is also a core upfront cost.
Finally, there are working capital and logistics costs, including transport, installation, initial spare parts, and early-stage marketing to onboard users and partners.
Together, these upfront investments create a durable, data-enabled cold chain platform that can generate recurring revenue while delivering climate, food security, and income benefits over many years.

label.plain: What is your projected revenue from this stream within the next 12 months?

field.label: What is your projected revenue from this stream within the next 12 months?
field.value:
Over the next 12 months, Solar Freeze projects to generate approximately USD 1.2 million in earned revenue from our solar-powered cold storage and PAYGO services.
This projection is based on scaling from our existing network to an additional 150–200 active cold storage hubs across Kenya and neighboring markets. Each hub serves an average of 300–500 farmers, traders, and agri-processors, charging small daily or per-crate fees for chilled storage, aggregation, and preservation of perishable produce such as fruits, vegetables, dairy, and fish.
On average, each cold storage unit generates USD 6,000–8,000 per year in user fees, driven by high utilization during harvest seasons and consistent demand from traders seeking to reduce spoilage. At 180 active units, this translates to USD 1.08–1.44 million annually, of which we conservatively forecast USD 1.2 million in the next 12 months.
Additional revenue comes from micro-franchise PAYGO repayments, where operators pay Solar Freeze a fixed daily or monthly fee for use of the solar cold room, as well as B2B service contracts with farmer cooperatives, humanitarian agencies, and food buyers that require reliable cold storage at aggregation points.
This revenue stream is already live, growing month-on-month, and provides a strong foundation for long-term financial sustainability and reinvestment into further expansion.

label.plain: When do you expect to reach breakeven for this stream (i.e., when revenue covers all associated costs)?

field.label: When do you expect to reach breakeven for this stream (i.e., when revenue covers all associated costs)?
field.value:
Solar Freeze expects to reach breakeven for this earned revenue stream within 12–18 months of the scale-up supported by this grant.
At the unit level, each solar-powered cold storage hub typically reaches operating breakeven within 3–5 months after installation, once it achieves steady utilization by farmers, traders, and aggregators. This is because daily user fees and PAYGO payments from micro-franchise operators begin flowing immediately, while operating costs (energy, maintenance, local staffing) are relatively low due to the use of solar power and remote monitoring.
At the organizational level, breakeven is achieved when revenue from the growing fleet of hubs covers central costs such as software, technical support, sales, and management. Based on our current cost structure and projected deployment of 150–200 additional hubs, we expect total monthly revenue to surpass operating expenses by month 15, after which the stream becomes cash-flow positive.
Once breakeven is reached, surplus revenue will be reinvested into deploying more cold storage units, expanding farmer reach, and strengthening local maintenance and data systems, enabling sustained growth without ongoing reliance on grant funding.

label.plain: How will you test and validate the financial viability of this stream before scaling?

field.label: How will you test and validate the financial viability of this stream before scaling?
field.value:
Solar Freeze will test and validate the financial viability of this earned revenue stream through a structured, data-driven pilot and staged scale-up approach before committing to full expansion.
First, we will deploy an initial cohort of 30–50 solar-powered cold storage hubs in diverse market contexts (rural farming centers, aggregation points, peri-urban markets, and refugee-hosting areas). These pilots will allow us to observe real customer demand, pricing sensitivity, utilization rates, and repayment behavior under different conditions. Each hub is equipped with IoT sensors and a PAYGO system that tracks daily usage, payments, temperature performance, downtime, and maintenance costs in real time, giving us precise unit-level financial and operational data.
Second, we will track core unit-economics metrics including average daily revenue per hub, cost of service delivery, maintenance frequency, repayment rates of micro-franchisees, and customer churn. We will benchmark these against target thresholds required for profitability and capital recovery. Hubs that do not meet performance benchmarks will be repositioned, repriced, or serviced through targeted marketing and farmer engagement.
Third, we will validate demand through signed usage agreements with farmer groups, cooperatives, traders, and institutional buyers before installing new hubs, reducing the risk of under-utilization.
Finally, we will use these verified data points to build a portfolio-level financial model, stress-testing scenarios for weather shocks, price changes, and payment delays. Only once this model demonstrates predictable cash flow, acceptable payback periods, and resilience across contexts will we scale the revenue stream to hundreds of hubs and bring in commercial capital.

label.plain: If available, please share any financial projections you have developed to support your earned revenue strategy.

field.label: If available, please share any financial projections you have developed to support your earned revenue strategy.
field.value:
Solar Freeze has developed a bottom-up financial model based on the performance of its existing PAYGO-enabled solar cold storage hubs and projected scale over the next 12 months.
On average, one solar cold storage hub generates approximately USD 25–40 per day from farmers, traders, and food vendors paying for cold storage services. At conservative utilization (USD 30/day), each hub generates about USD 10,950 per year. Direct operating costs per hub—including energy system maintenance, connectivity, field support, and operator commissions—average USD 4,000 per year, yielding a gross margin of roughly USD 6,950 per hub.
With an initial rollout of 100 hubs, annual revenue is projected at approximately USD 1.1 million, with gross profit of about USD 695,000. This margin covers central staff, software, and overhead while allowing capital recovery and reinvestment into additional units. PAYGO financing enables predictable monthly cash flows while reducing upfront cost barriers for micro-franchisees.
As scale increases to 300 hubs over three years, economies of scale in procurement, software, and maintenance reduce per-unit costs by an estimated 15–20%, improving margins further. These projections are supported by live PAYGO data from current deployments and provide a clear pathway to operational breakeven and long-term sustainability.

label.plain: If successful, how would this earned revenue stream help advance your organization’s mission and growth? How does it contribute to your long-term sustainability and impact goals?

field.label: If successful, how would this earned revenue stream help advance your organization’s mission and growth? How does it contribute to your long-term sustainability and impact goals?
field.value:
If successful, this earned revenue stream will become the backbone of Solar Freeze’s mission to end post-harvest loss and build climate-resilient rural economies. By generating predictable, recurring income from PAYGO cold storage services, Solar Freeze can move beyond grant dependency and sustainably expand access to cold chains for smallholder farmers, food vendors, and health facilities.
Revenue from each solar cold hub directly translates into more units deployed, more farmers served, and more women and youth earning income as micro-franchise operators. This creates a virtuous cycle: as more farmers reduce spoilage and increase their incomes, demand for cold storage grows, strengthening local food systems while generating cash flows that finance further expansion.
This model allows Solar Freeze to scale in line with real market demand rather than donor timelines. It supports long-term financial sustainability by covering operating costs, reinvesting in maintenance and upgrades, and funding new deployments in high-need regions. Over time, it also strengthens our ability to attract impact investors and blended finance partners, accelerating growth far beyond what grants alone can support.
Most importantly, the earned revenue model keeps impact and financial performance aligned. Every dollar earned represents food saved, emissions avoided, and livelihoods strengthened. This ensures that Solar Freeze can continue delivering climate adaptation, food security, and economic inclusion for vulnerable communities long after grant funding ends.

label.plain: How do you intend to use Follow-on Funding to support the development of financial sustainability within your organization?

field.label: How do you intend to use Follow-on Funding to support the development of financial sustainability within your organization?
field.value:
Follow-on Funding will be used as catalytic capital to strengthen Solar Freeze’s transition from a grant-dependent model to a sustainable, earned-revenue-driven enterprise. The funds will be invested directly into the systems, people, and infrastructure needed to scale our PAYGO solar cold storage revenue stream.
First, we will use the funding to deploy additional solar-powered cold storage units in high-demand farming and trading hubs. These units generate recurring income through daily PAYGO fees paid by farmers, vendors, and micro-franchise operators, allowing us to rapidly grow our revenue base while delivering immediate climate and livelihood impact.
Second, the grant will support the expansion of our micro-franchise network by training and onboarding more women and youth operators. This includes working capital for their startup kits, technical training, and business support to ensure high utilization, repayment, and long-term sustainability of each site.
Third, funds will be used to strengthen our digital and financial infrastructure, including our PAYGO billing platform, customer management systems, and AI-enabled monitoring tools that track usage, performance, and repayment in real time. This improves operational efficiency, reduces defaults, and increases investor and lender confidence.
Finally, we will invest in commercial readiness—building sales pipelines with food traders, cooperatives, and health facilities, refining pricing and unit economics, and preparing Solar Freeze to attract blended finance and impact investment. Together, these investments ensure Follow-on Funding directly accelerates our path to financial sustainability and scale.

label.plain: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:

field.label: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:
field.value: Green Farmlands mission is to improve smallholder farmers and vulnerable communities’ access to the tools, knowledge and market access they need to build sustainable livelihoods. Our vision is to see a Cameroon where smallholder farmers are financially stable and Vulnerable Communities are food secured.

label.plain: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.

field.label: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.
field.value: We carry out our activities through 03 main projects; -Green Basket which is an e-commerce platform aimed at linking smallholder farmers to urban markets via an online market where consumers can shop for fresh groceries from the comfort of their desk and mobile devices. Green Basket initiative bridges the gap between Cameroon’s rural smallholder farmers and urban consumers. Our online platform enables customers to easily order fresh groceries, which are sourced directly from farmers, transported via a modern cold chain, and made available at convenient neighborhood pickup points. - Farm School- Driven by smallholder’s expressed need to boost their production and productivity in a bid to increase their household income, we assist small holder farmers in engaging in sustainable agricultural practices by training them on new, improved and adaptable farm practices. We are rooted in the belief that that when farmers earn more income from their produce they can better feed their families, send their children to school, provide for their family’s health and invest in their farms thus making their communities economically stronger and more stable. -Adopt A Garden- In Cameroon, orphanages rely on fluctuating food donations. This nutritional insecurity threatens the healthy development of thousands of vulnerable children. This initiative offers a sustainable solution by empowering orphanages to grow their own food. We provide the necessary resources and training to establish on-site gardens, ensuring a reliable supply of fresh produce. Our goal is to achieve zero hunger in orphanages, giving every child the foundation they need to thrive.

label.plain: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

field.label: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

label.plain: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

field.label: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.
field.value: Our Green Basket platform is live, accessible to approximately 4.5 Million people in Douala. We have had an average of 11 people shopping via the platform every week ever since we launched in March 2025 and 9 farmers already supplying via Green Baskets. The Farm School has carried out the Black Soldier Fly Larvae training with the community, training over 18 smallholder farmers, young men and women agripreneurs and providing them with starter kits. Adopt A Garden has worked with 4 orphanages and 1 boarding school ensuring food security for over 360 orphaned and vulnerable children housed in these orphanages and boarding school.

label.plain: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:

field.label: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:
field.value: Fit to Navigate: Mission: Empower incarcerated individuals through wellness education & entrepreneurship, fostering well-being, sustainable wages, & reduced recidivism. Vision: A world where health transformation & supportive communities empower all to thrive. Unique Approach: This program combines fitness, entrepreneurship, and mental/emotional support, fostering a compassionate, wellness-centered mindset. Impact: 90% improved well-being. 100% employment upon release. 0% recidivism. Saves Ohio ~$3 million annually. We're the "x-factor" of rehabilitation, unlocking holistic well-being & empowering individuals to build brighter futures.

label.plain: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.

field.label: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.
field.value: Fit to Navigate has demonstrated significant traction in achieving its mission to empower incarcerated women through wellness education and entrepreneurship. Improved Health Outcomes: We have measured a 5-10% decrease in BMI and improved mental health scores among participants. Additionally, participants have self-reported increased emotional resiliency during periods of stress due to physical exercise. Reduced Recidivism: Compared to state broad data of 2/3, our program participants have a 0% recidivism rate, saving Ohio approximately $3,060,000.00 annually. This demonstrates our program's effectiveness in breaking the cycle of incarceration. Increased Employment Opportunities & Skill Development: 100% of program participants have gained employment upon release and experienced increased financial stability. This translates to $347,781.17 in increased workforce skill development for employers. Cost-Effectiveness & Community Impact: Fit to Navigate's cost per participant is significantly lower than the societal costs associated with a sense of community ($453,600.00) and emotional resilience ($1,312,588.80). We utilize a rigorous evaluation methodology, including Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs), to ensure the validity and reliability of our findings. This data-driven approach allows us to continuously refine our program and maximize our impact on the lives of incarcerated women.

label.plain: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

field.label: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

label.plain: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.

field.label: What milestones has your organization achieved since completing the fellowship? How has your work evolved or grown during this time? Please include any information about the impact growth, programmatic expansion, or increased community reach.
field.value: This Transformational Funding will enable Fit to Navigate to achieve the following key organizational milestones within the next year: Increase Program Reach: Establish new partnerships and invest in technology to reach 1500 incarcerated women annually by 2027. Engage at least 500 new incarcerated women in 2025 (current reach: 250). Enhance Program Impact: Demonstrate improved health outcomes, reduced recidivism, and increased participant employment rates. Build a Sustainable Ecosystem: Establish a network of program graduates as wellness educators within the prison system. Strengthen Organizational Capacity: Strengthen our data-driven approach to program evaluation to demonstrate impact and secure future funding. By achieving these milestones, Fit to Navigate will solidify its position as a leading organization empowering incarcerated women and contributing to a more just and equitable society.

label.plain: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:

field.label: Please describe the mission and vision of your organization:
field.value: The Tiekie Box Project seeks to reclaim and transform the way African Descendant Communities and the Diaspora engage with their Cultural Heritage, by elevating, expanding and empowering the work of global cultural rights activists, preservationists and descendant communities working to protect their heritage

label.plain: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.

field.label: Please describe the activities (products/ services etc.) your organization conducts to achieve its mission/vision.
field.value: Tiekie Box Project partners with descendant communities working tirelessly against direct and indirect threats to protect their marginalised heritage We invest in our communities by structuring our services according to the specific needs of the community and its goals for protection, preservation and promotion of the cultural heritage We support our communities by supplementing our service to include the advice of consultants and experts in the field of African Cultural Heritage As our communities’ holistic engagement with their heritage grows, so do the prospects for the preservation of African cultural heritage around the world

label.plain: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:

field.label: Please briefly describe the impact you’ve had thus far:
field.value: - Leading the campaign for Interpretation, Reburial and Memorialisation (Master Plan) on Saint Helena - Serving as the Lead Participant, Consulting and Impact Producer to the international award winning full length documentary A Story of Bones, - the Restitution of the story to the African continent through engaging with the State of The African Diaspora and the Kingdoms, Queendoms and Chiefdoms in Africa Queen Aidji awards the Memory of Humanity Prize to the “A Story of Bones” team | State Of African Diaspora - Sharing the story with the African Diaspora as the impact screening facilitator to communities - Member and partner to grassroots organisation in St. Eustatius in the Dutch Caribbean, which has led to 2 African Burial Grounds claiming UNESCO designations
